title: Brexit news Jeremy Corbyn Brussels Labour Party Michel Barnier meeting Theresa May
story: The hard-left Labour leader told Mr Barnier his party were prepared to vote down the Prime Minister&rsquos Brexit agreement if the deal does not meet their strict &ldquosix tests.Mr Corbyn and his shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer were hosted by bloc&rsquos controversial top civil servant Martin Selmayr before their high level talks with Mr Barnier.Speaking to reporters outside, Mr Corbyn explained the &ldquosix tests on which Labour will use to hold the British Government to account with in the future.&ldquoEssentially, the protection of jobs and the trade arrangements with the European Union and, of course, the issue surrounding the border in Ireland, he explained.Mr Corbyn added: What we did was set out our views, which we&rsquove set out very carefully and I must say he was very well aware of what both of us have said at our party conference and he then set out in broad terms what the progress is and what the timetable is and the importance of reaching an agreement.We discussed with him our six tests which are about ensuring that the manufacturing industry and supply chain is intact on both sides of the Channel and that EU nationals&rsquo position in Britain is secure and that there is no hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.The Labour Party leader revealed Mr Barnier was keen to hear about his party's Brexit plans, however, offered no opinion to his Brussels guests.                Brexit: Labour minister says party will 'COMPROMISE' on Brexit deal Mr Corbyn and Sir Keir's meeting is the sixth occasion they discussed Brexit with Mr Barnier.The shady meeting with Mr Selmayr, who oversees the EU&rsquos no-deal preparation, offers potential hints to how the bloc foresees Brexit&rsquos future, despite repeat claims it is working towards a deal.It is acknowledged Mr Selmayr requested the meeting in order to gain an understanding of Labour&rsquos plans directly from Mr Corbyn.At the Labour conference in Liverpool, the party&rsquos leader said opposition MPs &ldquowill vote against any reduction in right, standards or protections and oppose a deregulatory race-to-the-bottom.Mr Corbyn hopes by sinking the Prime Minister's Brexit deal he will be able to trigger a general election and launch himself into Downing Street.Despite being prepared to leave the country on the brink of a no-deal orce, Mr Corbyn spent two hours inside the Berlaymont building asking EU officials to do their best to strike a deal in order to avert a &ldquonational disaster in Britain.Brexit news: Jeremy Corbyn warns Michel Barnier of Labour's plan to vote down Government's deal (Image: )Prior to the showdown, the Labour leader said: &ldquoWith just weeks of negotiating time left, it&rsquos clear that UK-EU Brexit talks are in a perilous state. Time is running out and companies are losing patience with the absence of any clarity from the government.&ldquoCrashing out of Europe with no deal risks being a national disaster. That is why I&rsquom meeting EU officials today, and I will be urging them to do all they can to avoid a &lsquono-deal&rsquo outcome, which would be so damaging to jobs and living standards in both the UK and EU countries.He is demanding that Mrs May&rsquos post-Brexit deal offers a customs union with the EU, prevents a hard border in Ireland, protects jobs, people&rsquos rights at work and environmental and consumer standards.The cost of his support mirrors Labour&rsquos &ldquosix tests but is lesser than previous calls for a deal that achieves &ldquothe exact same benefits of both single market and customs union membership.Mr Corbyn and Sir Keir visited the European Commission while in Brussels to as part of the ceremony to rename a square in honour of the late Jo Cox, a Labour MP murdered in 2016.After paying their sombre tribute to their former colleague, the pair stopped off for a strategy meeting in a local brasserie, where Mr Corbyn feasted on a Greek salad.In an embarrassing mishap en route to the EU&rsquos headquarters, which could offer insight into Mr Corbyn&rsquos fiscal understanding, Labour aides were forced to scramble around for euros to pay their taxi driver.His communications chief Seumas Milne told waiting reporters: &ldquoThere&rsquos no end to the problems with this.An unimpressed Nigel Farage accused Mr Corbyn of being used as a useful idiot by the European Commission in their bid to secure a Brexit deal they are satisfied with.He told Express: Corbyn arranging to &nbspmeet Selmayr and Barnier was clearly an attempt to undermine negotiations after he promised to vote down May&rsquos deal.He is obviously believed by the European Commission to be a useful idiot.But I'm sure that working class people who voted leave will feel betrayed and angry at his ill- thought out stategy to betray British interests.

title: brexit news finance eu city london catherine mcguinness
story: Economies in both EU member states and the United Kingdom would be put under &ldquoimmediate and significant threat unless businesses could continue unimpeded by Brexit, according to City of London bosses.The stark warning comes as the City of London officials hold their annual gala in the Belgian capital, which plays host to high-ranking policymakers, MEPs and various officials.Catherine McGuinness, policy chairman for City of London Corporation, told her audience: &ldquoThere is already increasing concern in the sector about the current uncertainty on these issues.&ldquoConcern from institutions and indeed regulators both within the EU and UK and beyond.                'We've lost our way' May warned Tories risk handing power to Corbyn                TORY REBELLION: Party will not back Canada-style Brexit trade deal Catherine McGuinness, policy chairman for City of London Corporation&ldquoThe possibility that industry will not be able to service their clients poses an immediate and significant threat to financial stability and the smooth and orderly operation of both EU and UK economies.EU officials, on Thursday, insisted they are still working toward completing a withdrawal agreement and future partnership with Britain despite their increased no-deal planning.A spokesman for the European Commission said: We are working for a deal that&rsquos what matters. That&rsquos what our priority is and that&rsquos what we&rsquoll continue doing.Britain is presenting a more worrying image for Brussels, with EU ambassadors insisting no-deal preparedness should increase because of uncertainty in the House of Commons.Bankers have warned about the dangers of a no-deal Brexit (Image: )Catherine McGuinness, policy chairman for City of London Corporation (Image: )A private memo circulated ahead of a secret meeting sets out a vision for intensified contingency plans on both a domestic and EU level.The document reads: Preparedness work has to intensify in the months ahead at national as well as EU level, as uncertainty remains about the outcome of the negotiations and the ratification of a possible deal.Part of the reason is down to Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn threatening to sink Theresa May's Brexit deal with Brussels in order to trigger a general election.The hard-left leader offered the same warning to the EU's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier.Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn is threatening to sink Theresa May's Brexit deal (Image: REUTERS)After their Brussels meeting, Mr Corbyn told reporters: What we did was set out our views which we&rsquove set out very carefully and I must say he was very well aware of what both of us have said at our party conference and he then set out in broad terms what the progress is and what the timetable is and the importance of reaching an agreement.We discussed with him our six tests which are about ensuring that the manufacturing industry and supply chain is intact on both sides of the Channel and that EU nationals&rsquo position in Britain is secure and that there is no hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.After facing humiliation at an informal gathering of EU leaders, the Prime Minister must now face down furious party members who are also keen to leave her Chequers proposal dead in the water.European Council President Donald Tusk explained in a post-summit press conference that economic proposals in her plan don't work.His admission offered fresh hope to Brexiteers who have complained Chequers will deliver Brexit in name only.

title: Brexit News Jacob Rees Mogg Theresa May Chequers BBC Question Time
story: An audience member asked whether it was time for a Brexit supporter to lead the Brexit negotiations given that Theresa May&rsquos Chequers agreement hasn&rsquot been received well.The arch-Brexiteer seized the opportunity to blast the Prime Minister and the way she handled the EU summit in Salzburg.Having previously called the Chequers plan a &ldquodead duck, he said: &ldquoChequers may not even be a dying duck.&ldquoIt may be slightly more Count Dracula.                Tory Minister SAVAGES own party for &lsquotalking business down&rsquo                May could be FORCED OUT in MATTER OF MONTHS, former Tory leader warns&ldquoIt seems to be getting up at night and walk abroad but it doesn&rsquot really have much life in the sun.Regarding Chequers, the MP for North East Somerset once more insisted the blueprint &ldquois not leaving the EU, but &ldquoremaining bound by a European rulebook which is interpreted by the European Court of Justice.He added: &ldquoI think the negotiations have been badly conducted and we let the EU make the running of the negotiations.&ldquoWe have agreed to their establishment of terms of the negotiations and the timetable of the negotiations.Jacob Rees-Mogg has managed to come up with a new metaphor for the PM's Chequers agreement (Image: BBCGetty)The arch-Brexiteer seized the opportunity to blast the Prime Minister (Image: BBC)&ldquoI think this has not been impressive.When asked by BBC Question Time host David Dimbleby if Theresa May still believes in her deal, despite being brutally rejected by European leaders, Mr Rees-Mogg answered positively.He told Mr Dimbleby: &ldquoTheresa May still does believe in Chequers.&ldquoAnd I want her to change her policy.Jacob Rees-Mogg told Mr Dimbleby Theresa May still does believe in Chequers (Image: BBC)                Calling an election would be an act of utter madness, SAYS TIM NEWARK                 BBC Question time LIVE: David Dimbleby hosts Jacob Rees-Mogg &ldquoThis is what I am campaigning for.&ldquoAnd I think inevitably the policy will have to change because it does not have any supporters.If the EU is not going to accept it and Labour has committed to vote against it, a large number of Eurosceptic conservatives have committed to vote against it and the DUP does not seem in favour it, how does it get through the Commons?

title: Brexit news Jacob Rees Mogg wages EU BBC question time UK
story: Appearing on BBC Question Time, the Tory MP was answering a question from an audience member who complained to him about &ldquogreed-is-good capitalism and minimum wages for workers in care homes.His comments came after Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn took aim at large corporations in the UK, claiming they were too interested in profit in his conference speech on Wednesday.The arch-Brexiteer responded to his complaint by insisting that leaving the EU will result into a rise in income for the unprivileged.He explained: &ldquoIt is really important Brexit delivers for the people who are the least well off.                BREXIT BOMBSHELL: Johnson brands unveils his OWN plans for split                Tory Minister SAVAGES own party for &lsquotalking business down&rsquo&ldquoIt about lifting tariffs.&ldquoFood clothing and footwear are the most heavily tariffed items that come in.&ldquoAnd that has a greater effect on the income of the leat well off in our society.&ldquoCutting those costs will be good for the least well off.Jacob Rees-Mogg has claimed Brexit is the &ldquoreal shake-up the country needs (Image: BBC)Mr Rees-Mogg said leaving the EU will result into a rise in income for the unprivileged (Image: BBC)The audience member then asked Mr Rees-Mogg if he could guarantee him care home workers will get a significant pay rise with Brexit.The Tory MP asserted: &ldquoRestricting free movement of labour is highly likely to increase the wages of those on the minimum wage.&ldquoIn the country at large there are many migrants working in care homes.Director of Demos Polly Mackenzie, who sat on the panel along Mr Rees-Mogg during David Dimbleby&rsquos programme, strongly disagreed with the staunch Brexiteer.                Yanis Varoufakis lists TWO Brexit options available to BritainPolly Mackenzie strongly disagreed with the staunch Brexiteer (Image: BBC)She told him: &ldquoWages can only go up in care homes if the Government pays for the care homes, which means they have to put up taxes.In response, Mr Rees-Mogg stressed: &ldquoWages can go up if the economy grows and you make the economy grow when you make the right economic choices.&ldquoAnd then you get the tax revenues which will allow you to pay for what you want to pay for.There is no magic money tree.

title: Brexit news latest Philip Hammond cabinet Matt Hancock conservative party
story: Chancellor Philip Hammond and Health Secretary Matt Hancock had a spat on Monday over immigration (Image: )The Chancellor of the Exchequer called for flexibility in Home Office rules to allow companies to fill vacancies with low-skilled immigrants.The new Health Secretary Mr Hancock said companies should offer higher wages to attract UK citizens instead.At the Cabinet&rsquos weekly meeting on Monday the two men clashed on the topic of what our immigration policy should look like after the UK leaves the European Union.According to the Sun Mr Hancock, a trained economist, said: &ldquoWe shouldn&rsquot be stubby pencilled accountants because this is about a vision for the country.                TORY REBELLION: Party will not back Canada-style Brexit trade deal                 PM has &lsquosteel in her heart&rsquo Hunt warns rebelsMr Hammond used a restaurant in his constituency as an example of a company that cannot hire enough staff to wait the tables.Mr Hancock quipped that the restaurant should offer higher wages to entice more British people to do the job.The face-off between the two ministers, the 62-year old Chancellor and 39-year old Health Secretary took place in front of their colleagues at the meeting.A Cabinet minister who saw the exchange reportedly said: &ldquoMatt really went for Philip, and in front of all of us.10 Downing Street (Image: )&ldquoIt was quite a moment, and Philip didn&rsquot seem to know how to take it.Mr Hancock worked as George Osborne&rsquos chief of staff when he was Shadow Chancellor and is a strong supporter of Home Secretary Sajid Javid&rsquos plan to end low skilled immigration.Mr Hammond believes a liberal immigration system of all workers is essential to keeping the economy moving, due to the nation&rsquos ageing population.The Cabinet meeting on Monday was also the moment when Theresa May told her top table that her Chequers proposal will work, because cracks are beginning to appear between EU leaders.                END OF MAY: PM's closest ally drops HUGE HINT she could quit                 Rudd: Canada-plus would spark revoltChancellor Philip Hammond entering number 11 Downing Street (Image: )She apparently said: &ldquoSome heads of government want to be more constructive than the commission.Her words of confidence came after she returned from the Salzburg summit having been knocked down by EU leaders, who called her plan unworkable.A Cabinet source said: &ldquoThe noises coming from the member states themselves are certainly better than what&rsquos coming out of the commission.&ldquoBut it&rsquos a far cry to then say we&rsquoll be able to win them all over.

title: Brexit news UK BBC Question Time EU Theresa May European Union
story: The Question Time audience member insisted Britons have already voted to leave the European Union, and should not be forced to vote again.The audience member started his speech by pointing out the differences between Labour MP Ian Lavery and Brexit supporter Tory MP Jacob Rees-Mogg.He said: &ldquoI just want to say, two points. Ian, bless him, is a bit confused.&ldquoThe only way that you and Jacob are pulled apart is that he believes this country can go on to achieve better things, and you yourself don&rsquot believe we can, that&rsquos the difference.                Brexit chaos due to 'staggeringly USELESS politicians' The Question Time audience member then explained exactly why there should not be a second Brexit vote.He said: &ldquoWhen you say that it is a shambles, the reason it is a shambles is because whether you voted remain or leave or left or right, we should all two years ago have got behind the Prime Minister and the Government regardless of what you believed, and gone ahead against the EU as a country.&ldquoWe haven&rsquot done. When the EU is negotiating with us, they are not negotiating against a United Kingdom, they are negotiating with a ided one.&ldquoWhether you think we should leave or not, the people have already had the vote, this People&rsquos Vote that you all bang on about, we have had it, two years ago.&ldquoWe all decided to leave, that&rsquos it.Last week the Prime Minister claimed Brexit negotiations were at an &ldquoimpasse with the European Union after her Chequers blueprint was dealt a series of blows from EU leaders at Salzburg.Mrs May has also repeatedly said there will not be a second Brexit referendum.On Wednesday Home Secretary Sajid Javid tweeted: &ldquoFinally, one thing I had to repeatedly make clear: THERE WILL BE NO SECOND REFERENDUM.&ldquoDeeply unhelpful of some UK figures to travel around raising this prospect while so many working hard to land a deal.The shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer said this week the Labour Party would vote down any Brexit deal from the Government if it did not meet their six tests.Sir Keir also said &ldquonobody is ruling out Remain as an option should there be another referendum on Britain&rsquos relationship with the EU.Brexit news: Question Time audience member ripped into the panel (Image: BBC)Addressing the conference on Wednesday, Mr Corbyn insisted Labour would not overturn Brexit but questioned the conduct of the May Government during the negotiations with Brussels.Mr Corbyn said: &ldquoLabour respects the decision of the British people in the referendum but no one can respect the conduct of the government since that vote took place.As it stands, Labour will vote against the Chequers plan or whatever is left of it and oppose leaving the EU with no deal. And it is inconceivable that we should crash out of Europe with no deal &ndash that would be a national disaster.That is why if Parliament votes down a Tory deal or the government fails to reach any deal at all we would press for a general election.&ldquoFailing that, all options are on the table. Brexit is about the future of our country and our vital interests.Labour Party frontbenchers have repeatedly said their preference is a general election instead of another Brexit vote.

title: BBC Weather forecast UK latest update today weekend frost freeze Matt Taylor Met Office
story: BBC Weather forecaster Matt Taylor warned that temperatures would fall dramatically this evening edging close to freezing and covering much of the country in a bitter frost.Mr Taylor told viewers to expect a &ldquochilly night with lows of just 2C, and temperatures staying in the single figures across the country.Mr Taylor told viewers: &ldquoThe cooler air will push in tonight, more of a breeze through the next 24 hours, and the breeze picks up tonight, into Scotland too, bringing more in the way of rain in the Northern and Western Isles later.&ldquoBut really it will be a chilly night, a colder night than the night gone, with temperatures down into single figures UK wide.                Carol Kirkwood: BBC Breakfast star speaks out about future on show                BBC weather forecast UK: Temperatures PLUNGE to 2C as COLD STREAM hits&ldquoThere will be a touch of frost just about anywhere in the country.Mr Taylor said that due to a cold front, Friday morning would feel significantly cooler than yesterday&rsquos unseasonably baking heat, which saw a high of 24C in some areas of the country.The BBC weatherman reported: &ldquoTo begin the day, the coldest of the air is across Scotland, Northern Ireland and Northern England, the weather chart shows single figures and a touch of frost in one or two spots&ldquoA little bit milder in the South, that&rsquos because we&rsquove got a sheet of cloud which is a cold front which is bringing in the cooler air, that diminishes and breaks up to sunny skies.BBC Weather forecaster Matt Taylor predicted frost across the UK tonight (Image: BBC )He continued: &ldquoSo sunshine develops quite widely with a few showers maybe in the far North of Scotland, but for most, we&rsquoll have a dry day, with winds generally light way from the North of Scotland, and across some Eastern parts of England, but temperatures down on yesterday&rsquos values.&ldquoThe high 17-18C across the UK this afternoon, with the warmest of the air just lingering across the Channel Islands.&ldquoBut you&rsquoll be rewarded tomorrow morning as the weekend gets underway. There&rsquos lots of sunshine overhead, although a bit more cloud developing over Scotland and Northern Ireland tomorrow.&ldquoTemperatures will be generally around the teens.The Met Office has said that the weekend will bring patches of frost and fog, but we should see significant amounts of sunshine too.Met Officers forecasters said: &ldquoIt will be mostly fine over the weekend, with plenty of sunshine across central and southern parts.Cold nights, with patchy frost and fog. Generally changeable in the north and windy at times.With temperatures set to plummet in the coming weeks, the firm offers 6-4 that this winter will be the coldest on record.Coral&rsquos spokesman Harry Aitkenhead said: &ldquoTemperatures are set to tumble and everything looks to be leading up to a big freeze this winter.&ldquoIt seems almost certain that at some point in October the colder temperatures will arrive and they look set to bring snow with them.He added: &ldquoThis spring and summer saw a host of records broken for warm weather, but the glory days are slipping away.&ldquoThere&rsquos every chance of some coldest records being broken this winter, potentially starting with the coldest October on record.

title: Brexit news UK latest update Andre Neil Theresa May Salzburg summit
story: But her &ldquomy way or the highway stance has been questioned by the BBC host who said there are a number of alternatives to her controversial white paper plan.The BBC&nbsphost made a cutting dig at the Prime Minister as he questioned the credibility of her position, which is to leave the EU without a deal if there is no compromise from EU27 leaders on her Chequers&nbspBrexit proposals.Mr Neil said the EU had &ldquothrown her proposals off a cliff as he hosted BBC show This Week, adding &ldquomost of us thought that was the end of the beleaguered Chequers deal, which has also faced widespread criticism from many of her senior Tory MPs.But, Mr Neil continued, that was to &ldquounderestimate the stubborn resilience of the Maybot.He said: &ldquoWithin 24 hours the Prime Minister had rescued it from the slough of despond and asserted that Chequers was still the official UK bargaining position, and it was her way or the highway.&ldquoBut is that credible since five out of six MPs in the Commons are against leaving the EU on the basis of no deal, and is it even accurate, given that there are alternatives on offer, such as a comprehensive free trade deal, going much further than the one that the EU has recently completed with Canada?Fears have been growing the UK could crash out of the EU without a deal after member states rejected the Prime Minister&rsquos Chequers plan during an informal summit in Salzburg last week.European Council president Donald Tusk warned that Mrs May&rsquos Chequers proposals &ldquowould not work as it threatened to undermine the single market.Andrew Neil said that Mrs May's Chequer's proposals had been thrown off a cliff by EU leaders (Image: BBC )The Conservative Party has been plunged into a civil war over Mrs May&rsquos Chequers proposals, with senior Tories Jacob Rees-Mogg, David Davis and Boris Johnson united around a new &ldquoplan A plus which they claimed will give Britain the best trade deal in the world with the EU.The plan was drawn up by the Institute for Economic Affairs and mirrors the Brexit proposals put forward by the EU to ensure Britain breaks away cleanly and the EU&rsquos internal rules are not broken.The IEA plans call on ministers to seek a basic free trade agreement for goods and pursue regulatory freedom and trade independence.Former Home Secretary Amber Rudd has also said recently that she would back a second Brexit referendum rather than risk a no-deal exit from the European Union but said she was opposed to the Canada style deal favoured by some Chequers-opposing senior Tories.Mrs May has outright rejected the IEA proposals, insisting she would rather see Britain exit the bloc without an agreement because the Brexiteers&rsquo vision would result in northern Ireland being broken away.Asked on the flight to New York where she will attend the UN General Assembly, Theresa May was asked by the  which scenario is better between no-deal and Canada-plus.She said: &ldquoI have always said no deal is better than a bad deal.&ldquoI think a bad deal would be, for example, a deal that broke up the United Kingdom.

Sir Richard Branson brands Brexit a 'disaster' &amp calls for 're-think'                Brexit LIVE: Tory civil war erupts as MPs pull apart Theresa MayLabour MP Ian Lavery defended Labour&rsquos position of not taking any options &ldquooff the table as Britain continues to negotiate with the European Union.Polly Mackenzie, the Director of thinktank Demos claimed that if Parliament &ldquocould not make up its mind over Brexit the only people who could make the final decision about the &ldquokind of Brexit we want are the British people.Ms Mackenzie added that it felt &ldquouncomfortable to &ldquosay there ought to be another vote, but claimed she did not think there seemed to be &ldquoan alternative option.Ayesha Hazarika, a comedian who was also on the BBC panel, claimed Brexit negotiations were an &ldquoabsolute shambles.Ms Hazarika also said it was &ldquoundemocratic not to give the British people another say on leaving the European Union.Speaking on BBC&rsquos Question Time Jacob Rees-Mogg spelt out why there should not be another Brexit vote. He said: &ldquoOn the second referendum question. How many votes have we got to have on this?&ldquoIn 2015 we had a general election which decided that we would have the referendum. We then had the referendum and then we had a general election where both major parties said they would implement the result of the referendum.&ldquoIt seems to me that there is a smallish group of people who are so determined for us not to leave the European Union that they want to make us go on voting until they get the result they want.&ldquoI don&rsquot think the British people are going to fall to that. Democracy requires that you implement that&nbspresult&nbspbefore you start deciding what you are going to do in another referendum.Brexit news: Question Time audience member praised Rees-Mogg in passionate tirade (Image: BBC)Mr Rees-Mogg also said: &ldquoIt is really important Brexit delivers for the people who are the least well off. title: BBC Weather forecast UK temperatures Met Office latest news
story: BBC Weather forecaster Helen Willetts warned temperatures would &ldquodrop like a stone across the country on Friday evening.Temperatures in the south of the UK reached 23C on Thursday, but Willetts claimed the warm air was expected to &ldquodisappear.The BBC Weather forecaster said: &ldquoAs we go through this evening and overnight the chilly northwesterly winds will push that weather front southwards so that warmth we have been enjoying across the south, disappears.&ldquoIt will still be quite pleasant enough, but temperatures will be back down to where they should be really for this time of year.                UK weather forecast: BIG FREEZE begins with &lsquoFROST&rsquo                 BBC weather forecast UK: Britain set for 10 degree DROP in temperature&ldquoThe end of the day sees that cloud coming into the north of England, the north of Wales, but at the same time, it starts to brighten up across Scotland and possibly Northern Ireland later with sunshine.&ldquoBut it is ahead of that weather front where we are seeing temperatures into the low 20C&rsquos now.&nbspBehind that, as I say, we have got that cold air.&ldquoSo what happens overnight is that weather front with its attendant cloud and possible drizzle will hold the temperatures up in the south and it is the turn of the north of the country, in&nbspfact,&nbspmany parts of the country, north of the M4 to have a chilly night.Moving into Friday, the BBC Weather forecaster added: &ldquoLots of sunshine coming through but note the temperature, lower across the board tomorrow, and we have got a keen northeasterly wind blowing across East Anglia and the southeast as well which will accentuate the cooler feel of the day compared with today.&ldquoDipping of a bit more cloud in the west on Friday night, but elsewhere again temperatures will plummet, drop like a stone, ground frost quite widely in the countryside. Autumn is with us.&ldquoBut, a beautiful start to our day on Saturday, could be a little bit of mist and fog around, given the winds will have fallen light, but that will clear mid-morning.The BBC Weather forecaster also predicted another dip in temperatures for the UK on Sunday.The Met Office has also forecast temperatures to dip on Friday evening, with &ldquocold nights over the weekend.The national weather service update for Friday reads: &ldquoAfter a cloudy start in the south it will be a fine day with good spells of sunshine.BBC Weather forecast: Temperatures to plummet on Friday evening (Image: BBC)&ldquoCloudier and breezier in the north, with some rain. Feeling cooler.The Met Office forecast for Saturday to Monday adds: &ldquoMostly fine over the weekend, with plenty of sunshine across central and southern parts.&ldquoCold nights, with patchy frost and fog. Generally changeable in the north and windy at times.With temperatures forecast to &ldquoplummet leading bookmakers have slashed odds to 1-2 that snow will fall in the UK during October.Coral&rsquos Harry Aitkenhead said: &ldquoTemperatures are set to tumble and everything looks to be leading up to a big freeze this winter.&ldquoIt seems almost certain that at some point in October the colder temperatures will arrive and they look set to bring snow with them.

title: Typhoon Trami Japan elections storm Okinawa
story: The typhoon may disrupt the elections on sunday (Image: )Typhoon Trami is set to batter Japan with 125mph wind and torrential rain, bringing flooding chaos to the islands.It is expected to make landfall in the next 48 hours, causing power cuts and potential landslides.The powerful storm is expected to pass over the Okinawa Prefecture this weekend and candidates for governor are making efforts to get voters to the polls ahead of time.Advanced polls have been open since September 14 and over 90,000 have already cast their ballots according to the election commission - an increase in 75 percent over the past period in the 2014 election.The Okinawa Election Commission announced that residents living in the town of Taketomi and island chain Tsukenjima, will go to the polls early.This is because it would be difficult to safely deliver ballot boxes to the voting booths by ship, given the approaching storm.Maiko Shigehisa of the election commission said: &ldquoWe&rsquore keeping an eye on the typhoon, but as of today, there are no discussions about moving up the election elsewhere on Okinawa.The two main candidates are Atsushi Sakima, backed by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, and Denny Tamaki.Typhoon Trami trajectory (Image: JOINT TYPHOON WARNING CENTRE)The election could impact the controversial plan to relocate a US Marine Corps Air Station Futenma in Ginowan to a partially offshore facility now under construction at Henoko on the northern part of the island.Mr Sakima has chosen to avoid discussing the issue whereas Mr Tamaki has come out in opposition to the plan.Both sides have said the typhoon could play a factor in the final results.A spokesman for Sakima&rsquos office, Jinichiro Asato, said: &ldquoIf Okinawa Prefecture gets a warning for severe winds, then we&rsquoll suspend outdoor canvassing with our campaign truck.                Typhoon Trami tracker MAPPED: JAPAN now on alert                Typhoon Trami path MAPPED: Super Typhoon to SLAM into JapanAstronaut Alexander Gerst managed to take stunning photos of the eye of the storm (Image: ALEXANDER GERST)&ldquoAt that point, our volunteers will hit the phones to appeal to voters.He added: &ldquoIf the typhoon moves slowly, it could affect voter turnout on Sunday.&ldquoBut if it moves through quickly, turnout probably won&rsquot be affected.A spokeswoman for Tamaki&rsquos office said there were no plans yet to make changes to the campaign.Another photograph from the astronaut at the International Space Station (Image: ALEXANDER BERST)She said: &ldquoBut at this point, we&rsquore watching the situation carefully.&ldquoAll we can do is to tell people, especially the elderly people who might not be able to move about easily, that the weather is OK now so they might wish to get out and vote.The typhoon was forecast to pass over the smaller islands earlier Saturday morning before turning to pass over the main island on Sunday.

title: EU news emmanuel macron viktor orban matteo salvini
story: The French President took aim at Hungary&rsquos Prime Minister Viktor Orban and Italy&rsquos deputer prime minister Matteo Salvini by warning them their steer towards nationalism is a &ldquobig mistake.The pair have teamed up to form a conservative, anti-migration political alliance ahead of next May&rsquos European Parliament election and labelled Mr Macron their number one enemy.Both nations have taken a hardline stance against immigration, with Italy&rsquos new government refusing to let migrant rescue ships dock and Hungary passing laws to punish anyone found to help asylum seekers.The French president accused both leaders of &ldquoplaying on citizens fears to gain support for their anti-immigration policies which &ldquorevert to populism. He said &ldquocooperation and &ldquocollective change is the best way to reform the EU.                China news: Beijing hits back at Trump's midterm hacking claims wit...Speaking after Bloomberg Global Business Forum at the Plaza Hotel in New York,&nbspEmmanuel Macron&nbspsaid: &ldquoWhat I propose for their country, is not a solution to address migration, but it is incompatible within Europe.&ldquoViktor Orban doesn&rsquot want to take migrants from Italy, he is the worst enemy of Italy because nationalism is just generalised war.&ldquoMy objective is to first deliver reforms in France and Europe, to show it works, it is better for people, it provides results to decrease unemployment, to provide more security.&ldquoSecond, I want to convince people that cooperation is the best way to address our collective challenges, migration, climate change and digital challenges.Emmanuel Macron accused Hungary of starting a war  (Image: BLOOMBERG )Emmanuel Macron said Hungary is waging war with his step towards nationalism  (Image:   )Speaking after Bloomberg Global Business Forum at the Plaza Hotel in New York,&nbspEmmanuel Macron&nbspsaid: &ldquoWhat I propose for their country, is not a solution to address migration, but it is to be compatible with Europe.&ldquoViktor Orban doesn&rsquot want to take migrants from Italy, he is the worst enemy of Italy because nationalism is just generalised war.&ldquoMy objective is to first deliver reforms in France and Europe, to show it works, it is better for people, it provides results to decrease unemployment, to provide more security.&ldquoSecond, I want to convince people that cooperation is the best way to address our collective challenges, migration, climate change and digital challenges.                Queen and Philip pose with dead tiger years before Prince William                 A38 traffic latest: Multi-vehicle crash brings A38 to standstill at...&ldquoAll these challenges are impossible to be addressed at a national level.When quizzed over the actions of Hungary&rsquos Prime Minister Mr Orban and Mr Salvini, Italy&rsquos deputy prime minister and leader of Lega, Mr Macron said &ldquoclosing borders and &ldquoreverting to nationalism was not the answer to the EU&rsquos problems.Mr Macron added: &ldquoThey are playing in to fears. I don&rsquot believe in globalisation without any protection for workers and for people.&ldquoI don&rsquot think we can precisely address our weaknesses and the deep needs and feelings of our people by closing borders and reverting to nationalism. I think this is a big mistake.Mr Orban is currently on a collision course with Brussels as he works towards boosting his country&rsquos sovereignty.Emmanuel Macron also criticised Italy's Matteo Salvini  (Image:  )Member states voted to begin so-called Article 7 proceedings which could see Hungary lose its voting rights in the EU after Mr Orban pushed through controversial domestic laws.He wants to take control of universities and the media, and has imposed a law which punishes lawyers, charities and activists for helping asylum seekers.The bloc has also been hit by a rise in support for far-right, anti-immigration parties in national and regional elections, following the unprecedented refugee crisis that pushed millions of people fleeing war and poverty in the Middle East and Africa to seek refuge in Europe.But the French liberal said member states were better together when addressing the challenges faced by the bloc, including migration, climate change and digital problems.Mr Macron has repeatedly warned next year&rsquos parliamentary election will be an open battle between anti-immigrant nationalists and pro-Europe progressives.But Mr Orban and Mr Salvini have vowed to plough on with their plans to reform the bloc.Mr Salvini said: &ldquoWe want to change Europe&rsquos commission. We want to protect our borders. We are going to fight pro-migrant policies supported by Mr Macron and George Soros.And the Hungarian hardliner echoed his ally&rsquos words, saying: &ldquoEuropean elections are coming. We have to change a lot of things. There are two sides at the moment in Europe.&ldquoOne is led by Mr Macron, who is supporting migration. The other one is supported by countries who want to protect their borders. Hungary and Italy belong to the latter.

story: President Macron angered British officials at the informal EU summit in Salzburg, Austria (Image: Peter ByrnePA)Asked at a climate change summit in New York if he UK could remain in the EU if voters overturned the 2016 referendum decision, he replied: &ldquoFor sure.&nbspSaying the French would not create obstacles he added: &ldquoThis is about history, not about domestic interests.President Macron angered British officials at the informal EU summit in Salzburg, Austria, last week by crowing about how difficult the Brexit negotiations had become.&nbspHe urged the EU to block the Chequers proposal for a trade deal as &ldquonot acceptable. story: It sent the euro plummeting 0.8 percent against the US dollar yesterday before rallying slightly.Italy will use the budget deficit to increase public spending, in defiance of economy minister Giovanni Tria.But things won&rsquot be &ldquopretty for Italy, according to experts.Armando Marozzi, analyst at Medley Global Advisors, said: From now on things will be tough for Italy.The European Commission will reject this budget and next month ratings agencies are likely to downgrade Italian bonds.Alessandro Balsotti, fund manager with JCI Capital, said: The 2.4 percent figure is for sure at the top end of expectations after swinging in the last six weeks from fears of touching or exceeding 3 percent to the unexpectedly more sober 1.6 percent, and recently zoning in on a possible compromise of around 2 percent.&nbsp&ldquoLet's see today if a number that could send us on a collision course with Europe prompts further losses.The euro today rose 0.1 percent to 1.1650 after dropping more than 0.8 percent on Thursday on uncertainty over Italy's budget deficit.Italy's interior minister Matteo Salvini has lauded the decision (Image: )Jasper Lawler, head of research at the London Capital Group, said the euro was remaining resilient in early trading, adding: &ldquoThis means the markets are seeing this as a domestic issue right now, rather than something that is an immediate risk to the eurozone region.&nbsp&ldquoThere is still scope for political jitters to hit sentiment for the euro as the day progresses.One analyst said debate over the budget was an indication of the power struggle which had been waged in the heart of the Italian Government between coalition partners Lega and Five Star, as well as the economy minsiter Giovanni Tria.Christoph Rieger, rates strategist with Commerzbank, said: The budget compromise has a bad taste to it. Clearly, the 5-Star Movement is the winner. It makes clear what the balance of power is within the government &ndash namely that Tria has been overruled.5SM's Luigi Di Maio hailed it as a budget for the people (Image: )&ldquoIt leaves him damaged. It seems clear that he is just staying as finance minister to avoid chaos, but that's not a very good basis for future fiscal policy.The 2.4 percent figure does not break the EU&rsquos deficit limit of three percent of GDP - but is unlikely to impress EU bosses, with Economic and Monetary Affairs Commissioner, Pierre Moscovici, said last month: &ldquoIt&rsquos in Italy&rsquos interest to control public debt.&nbspThe figure is also far higher than the 1.6 percent Mr Tria wanted, and will be used to bankroll a raft of measures including a basic income for job seekers, a minimum pension of &euro780 a month, and an income tax cut for one million workers, likely to cost &euro20 billion over three years.Mr Salvini and Luigi Di Maio, leader of coalition partners the Five Star Movement (5SM) said in a joint statement after meetings with Tria: There is an accord within the whole government for 2.4 percent, we are satisfied, this is a budget for change.                Italian MEP&rsquos STERN threat to EU 'SUPER BUREAUCRACY'                ITALY CRISIS: Eurozone exit would be &lsquoCATASTROPHIC'Economy minister Giuseppe Tria had wanted a much lower figure of 1.6 percent (Image: )Mr Di Maio subsequently added: &ldquoToday Italy has changed, we have drafted a budget for the people.&nbspThis 2.4 percent is a victory for Italian citizens. This budget will allow the economy to grow and investments to rise again.Mr Salvini, who is on a trip to Tunisia, said: The right to work, to happiness of millions of Italian people is worth a few little numbers.&nbspWriting on Facebook, Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte said the budget goals were considered, reasonable and courageous and would ensure more robust economic growth and significant social progress for our country.He said the budget plan included the biggest programme of public investments ever carried out in Italy.The decision to run a 2.4 percent deficit has financial markets worried (Image: )The end result has created the perception that Mr Tria has caved in under pressure from populist politicians &ndash but speaking late yesterday, a spokeswoman for him insisted &ldquohe&rsquos remaining in his post.Arne Petimezas, an analyst with the AFS group, said given Italy&rsquos high levels of debt, the situation &ldquocertainly isn&rsquot pretty.He added: &ldquoFurthermore, the so-called structural deficit is probably going to get even worse. And it was already in violation of the EU's fiscal compact.&nbsp&ldquoIn any case, given the wild (post-)election promises, 2.4 percent of GDP is still very moderate, and up only slightly from last year's 2.3 percent.Roberto Lattice, fund manager with Iffiest, said: I'm a bit surprised and not a little perplexed. I was expecting something more reasonable but we didn't get it.&nbsp&ldquoI thought Tria was a bulwark but he wasn't and probably stayed on in reply to Italian President Sergio Mattarella's request to avoid market turbulence.

title: second referendum labour john mcdonnell keir starmer
story: While Theresa May has continually ruled out holding a second vote, many have thrown their weight behind another vote on our EU status. Heres the latest.While a number of politicians and celebrities have added their voice to growing calls for a second referendum this has always been rejected by Downing Street.In September 2018 the mayor of Manchester Andy Burnham backed a second Brexit vote  there was a no-deal scenario - but warned it could trigger social unrest.Theresa Mays official spokesman has said: The British people have voted to leave the EU and there is not going to be a second referendum under any circumstances.It could depend on how Brits perceive Parliamentary squabbles over Mrs Mays Chequers deal.Theresa May called on Jeremy Corbyn to rule out a second vote on EU membership during PMQs, but the Labour leader failed to respond.Labour has been in a muddle over the issue too — with the leadership refusing to commit to a call for a second vote despite cries from centrist MPs and members.A sizeable section in the party want a second referendum and pressure is mounting on the left-wing leader.The GMB, one of the UKs biggest trade unions, called for a vote on the final Brexit deal.Later in September 2018, Mayor of London Sadiq Khan dramatically called for another EU referendum — saying that people must be given the opportunity to reject Brexit.The Mayor of London, who is an avowed remainer, argued Britain is facing either a bad deal or “no deal” which he says will hit jobs and living standards.Referring to the worst case scenerios, Mr Khan said: “They are both incredibly risky and I don’t believe Theresa May has the mandate to gamble so flagrantly with the British economy and people’s livelihoods.”Party bosses have hinted theyll back a second referendum - but Jeremy Corbyns closest ally, John McDonnell, has ruled out keeping Britain in the EU.Labour bigwigs set out a new policy which could see the party supporting a fresh referendum  Theresa May refuses to call a General Election.But the policy was blown apart just hours later when Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell suggested the second referendum wouldnt include an option to remain in the EU.Speaking on the BBC’s Today programme, the hard-left veteran said: “We’ve said we want a people’s vote  we can’t get a General Election.“We accept the last referendum - we want a General Election,  we can’t get that we want some form of democratic option.”Asked what form a second referendum would take, Mr McDonnell said: “It will be on the deal itself. We will respect the referendum.”Speaking to ITVs Good Morning Britain, he added: It will be about whether you accept the deal or not or whether you send people back to negotiate a proper deal.And he told BBC Radio 5 Live: My big worry is that  we go for a referendum which is seen as just a simple re-run we could ide the country again, we could get almost the same result or  its slightly dferent that people demand another referendum.Following John McDonnells comments, Labours Shadow Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union Keir Starmer reaffirmed that the party have not ruled out calling for a second Brexit referendum.Ahead of a vote at the party conference on Tuesday, September 25, the shadow Brexit secretary said that a motion on the highly isive question that has dominated the event in Liverpool doesnt rule out Remain.Starmer told the party conference: We want a General Election to sweep away this failed government.He added: And having swept them away we want to install a radical Labour government capable of transforming this country. And thats what should happen after two years of negotiations ending in failure.But  thats not poss we must have other options, and that must include campaigning for a public vote.Starmer said: No one is ruling out remain as an option.Paddy Power has odds of 2/1 on another EU referendum before the end of 2019.A poll carried out by NatCen and The UK in Changing Europe revealed 59 per cent of voters would now vote to remain in the EU, while 41 per cent would opt to leave.The author of the poll John Curtice urged caution over the finding.He said the interview panel was skewed towards remain, and that some of the sht was among those who did not take part in the original Brexit referendum.  The first referendum on EU membership took place in 1975.Two-thirds of voters  backed the continued membership of the European Economic Community, which the UK had joined only two years before.Under Harold Wilsons leadership, the Labour Party was trying to present to the public a dferent version of EEC membership to get a better deal.The EEC was integrated into the European Union after it was created in 1993.In the summer of 2016, Britain voted to leave the EU after 17.4million people backed Leave compared to 16.1million Remain voters.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The cooler weather comes as a shock end to the Indian Summer - heres what you need to know.Friday looks be dry and sunny but will be much cooler as temperatures drop from 24.5C on Thursday to around 18C.Met Office spokeswoman Nicola Maxey told The Mirror: “It is going to turn colder towards the weekend with a northerly flow of Arctic air bringing temperatures down compared to earlier in the week.“Friday will feel colder and we could see some patchy frosts first thing, daytime temperatures will reach the mid-teens at best and it will feel colder in the north.“Overnight into Saturday we could see more widespread frosts with temperatures widely dropping, anywhere in the country could see a frost.She added: “There will be blustery showers around on Saturday and along northern coasts there will be the risk of gales.“There may be some sleet or wet snow over high ground in the north on Sunday night.”Scotland will get some light showers throughout Friday but for the rest of the country it will remain “dry, fine and sunny” for most parts.Looking into the weekend, temperatures will remain the same at 18C on Saturday after a dry night, but will get colder still on Sunday as maximum temperatures drop to between 15-16C.Monday will see a chilly start to the day with showers in the east and cloud in the west.The Met Office warns the public and emergency responders of severe or hazardous weather which has the potential to cause danger to le or widespread disruption through the National Severe Weather Warning Service.The Met Office issues warnings for thunderstorms, rain, snow, wind, fog and ice.These warnings are given a colour depending on a combination of the likelihood of the event happening and the impact the conditions may have.There are a number of ways you can find out whether your area is at risk from flooding.The Environment Agency, the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and Natural Resources Wales update their warnings 24 hours a day via the Floodline number.The highest 24-hours of rainfall in England occurred in Cumbria on December 5, 2015.According to the Met Office 341.4mm of rain fell at Honister Pass, Cumbria, in 24-hours, a new UK rainfall record, while at Thirlmere 405mm also set a new record for two consecutive rain-days.Sloy Main Adit in Scotland experienced 238mm on January 17, 1974.And on November 11, 1929, Lluest Wen Reservoir in Wales was flooded with 211mm of rainfall.The record for Northern Ireland was in 1968 at Tollymore Forest, County Down, which saw 159mm.

title: jane moore katie price rehab romance
story: The second time was in January 2016, behind the scenes of Loose Women.In the intervening years, I had made several waspish remarks about her on this very page  so fully expected a frosty exchange.But she was disarmingly self-deprecating, funny and, to my utter surprise, very much a woman’s woman.“I know you think I’m a nightmare,” she said matter-of-factly. “And you’re probably right. But I think we’re going to get on.”She was right. We did. The other panellists liked her too.Predominantly mothers, we treated her as one might a naughty niece you were particularly fond of, rolling our eyes and smiling affectionately as she regaled us with the latest relationship drama in her le.But despite her no-nonsense, often humorous delivery, there was always a faint “here we go again” sadness behind her eyes and, as I saw it, a low self-esteem that might explain the constant cosmetic alterations and propensity to criticise herself before anyone else could.After reading the recent headlines of wild nights out and rap songs about cocaine, it’s easy to think that Katie is a party girl who has largely abandoned her children as an inconvenience to the carefree lestyle she longs to have.And, judging by yesterday’s letters page, plenty of you do.Before getting to know her, I might have shared that view. But now I see her admittedly destructive behaviour as a cry for help and I’m relieved that, finally, she’s in to rehab to get it.Once, in a rare flash of what I feel is the real Katie, she told me that her Holy Grail was to find a decent, dependable man who could pay the bills while she stayed home and ran a large, chaotic farmhouse full of children and animals.Her favourite night of the week was Friday, when she would wipe off her “work face”, slip in to her old trackie bottoms and call in a takeaway for her, her now estranged third husband Kieran and the kids.Anyone who has seen her interacting with Harvey, her severely disabled eldest son, will know that she’s a fundamentally devoted mother doing her best  in often trying circumstances.Remember her in the I’m A Celebrity jungle? Free of make-up, her hair in braids, tackling each challenge with an admirably no-nonsense bravado? To my mind, that’s the real Katie — the rest is just noise.But without doubt, she has a self-destructive streak when she feels let down.So, after catching Kieran having an affair with her “best friend”, forgiving him, then catching him again with someone else, it was inevitable that a fall was coming. Her mum Amy said at the weekend: “Kate has been her own worst enemy and behaved like an idiot at times but she has been tearing herself apart for years.“All the men in her le have used Katie, and never, ever leave her alone . . . Kieran almost destroyed Kate with his behaviour, Alex  has been as bad, and Pete  likes to portray himself as perfect . . . they all know that  they wind her up, she will react.“Kate is stupid for reacting, but these men need to look at how they are behaving and take some responsibility.”Wise words. And Katie needs to heed them as much as her former husbands.She’s always been disarmingly frank about the incidents in her le that would have sent many of us over the edge — not least being sexually abused when she was just six years old. But now it’s time for her to stop shrugging them off as “just one of those things” and take a long, hard look at how they’ve shaped her often destructive behaviour patterns as an adult.I hope she sticks with the therapy and, ultimately, finds contentment.HOT on the stilettos of Stormy Daniels’ lurid description of Donald Trump’s manhood, singer Cher has been regaling us with tales of her former lovers.Tom Cruise is in her “top five” but legendary lothario Warren Beatty was, apparently, a disappointment.Cher, 72, explains: “Not that he wasn’t technically good, but I didn’t feel anything.”We remain blissfully unaware of whether she means emotionally or physically.EAGLE-EYED travellers boarding a flight operated by Hong Kong airline Cathay Pacic noticed this glaring spelling error on the side of the plane.Though it grieves me greatly, spelling errors or “typos” are now commonplace in everyday exchanges via text, tweet or email, but it never ceases to amaze me when they’re writ large on something as expensive as a sign, billboard or, er, Boeing 747.Does no one check these things before literally advertising their ignorance? Seems not.And so, we are entertained by such gems as Shoplters Will Be Prostituted, Chris Is Risen, All Busniesses Open As Usual, Pay and Display Apples In This Area, Costumers Only, Parrallel Parking, No Trough Road and Pedestrain Crossing, to name but a few.And don’t even get me started on missing or misplaced apostraffy’s…WHEN cookery presenter Nadiya Hussain was picked to bake the Queen’s birthday cake in 2016, she recalls feeling that it was an opportunity to act against Islamophobia.“Everybody thinks it, ‘Oh God, who let the Muslim woman near the Queen with a kne?’” she says now. “Let’s address that elephant in the room, because they did.”Nope. Actually, I remember thinking, “Oh, it’s that lovely woman who won Bake Off and made Mary Berry cry tears of joy”.Sorry to disappoint, Nadiya.Quite right too.Particularly as the majority of them are now more recognisable than the “celebrities” they’re dancing with.HOLLYWOOD director Sam Mendes says his now defunct marriage to Kate Winslet struggled because he “was not very comfortable being married to a celebrity . . . it made me feel self-conscious”.Couldn’t he have worked that out before they trotted down the aisle?VIDEO game designers are working on giving avatars real-le emotions to make the experience more authentic.Will they include a frustrated parent yelling: “Get off that bloody thing before you turn in to someone with the physical and people skills of an atrophied three-toed sloth?No, thought not.ACTRESS Helena Bonham Carter says she used a psychic to contact Princess Margaret so she could perfect her role as the Queen’s sister in the forthcoming third series of The Crown.She claims Margaret told her she’s “doing a great job”.Hmmm. From what little one knows of the feisty royal, “fack orf” seems more likely.FRANK SPRINGETT is 91, his we Mary is 86 and they have been married for 67 years.Frank is deaf and suffers from arthritis, Mary has severe Alzheimer’s, and both are being looked after in the same Warwickshire-based care home using funds from the sale of their house.However, the money is now running low and while social services will continue to partially pay for Mary’s care, it says former factory worker Frank has to look after himself.Meaning that 70 years after they met, they face being separated for the first time.“We fear  they are torn apart, the strain will kill them,” says their daughter Joanne, 57.With seemingly endless funds being readily shelled out to help accommodate those  who seek asylum in Britain, how sad that someone who has paid in to the system all their le gets so let down when they need it most.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brussels eu press regulation sun
story: Justice commissioner Vera Jourova was riled by our front page labelling EU leaders “dirty rats” over their tactics.She accused the UK media of spreading “disinformation” and suggested “smart regulation”.Speaking in Austria, Ms Jourova said: “Media can build the culture of dialogue or sow isions, spread disinformation and encourage exclusion.“The Brexit debate is the best example of that. Do you remember the front page of a popular British daily calling the judges the ‘enemy of the people’?Or just last week, the EU leaders were called ‘dirty rats’ on another front page.Almost daily we could find examples of stories that are spiced up to point out the enemy, to paint the picture black and white.I would advocate for a European approach to media based on quality and smart regulation,  needed.But Tory MEP Amjad Bashir said: “Commissioners should not be trying to shackle the Press.“We politicians do not always like what journalists write, but they have to be free to report the news as they see it.The vibrancy and iety of our newspapers is one of the things that makes Britain great.People have to learn to take the rough with the smooth.Otherwise we are on a slippery slope to state control and oppression.Mr Bashir’s colleague Ashley Fox added: “A free and unfettered media is vital.” EU officials insisted there was no new legislative action in the pipeline in terms of media regulation and that Ms Jourova had been talking about broadcasters.A Commission spokeswoman said she was merely trying to “trigger a discussion”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: And some of them chanting the slogan “from the river to the sea” favoured by Hamas and the PLO, who demand the liquidation of Israel.Lovely people.That will have put to rest any worries the British Jewish community might have, no? And they STILL claim they’re not anti-Semitic.Some dizzy bint then got up and demanded a general strike. Right now! Everyone out! Why? To “bring down” the hated Tories. Basically, a spoiled child’s temper tantrum.But she got a standing ovation from the deranged lefties who have taken over the party, Momentum.It was strikes which brought down Labour,  you remember. Strike after strike. The damage that did to the country, back in the late 1970s. And the damage it did to Labour — out of power for almost 20 years.And the pie-in-the-sky policy announcements. Apparently they’re going to create 400,000 “green” jobs. What the hell is a green job? Mowing the lawn?And who is going to pay for this extravagance?Just how high are taxes going to rise so Corbyn can staple a useless and hideous wind turbine on everybody’s forehead, so we can be greener than green? Sixty per cent, seventy per cent?More b******s. Labour intends to ensure that more and more nursery staff are educated to degree level. Why? Do you really need a degree to clip four-year-old Jayden around the ear and settle the other toddlers down to watch In The Night Garden?Superfluous degrees are one of the big scandals of our time.Hundreds of thousands of kids being duped into taking useless courses at third-rate “universities” and being saddled with a mountain of debt. And unable to find work.Dirt cheap childcare for everyone, even the rich. Paid for, then, by who?Nationalisation of the water and power companies and the railways. Well, I’ve got no objection to that. But you still have to keep asking yourself — where is the money coming from?And on Brexit? Scarcely a word. The most important issue facing the country right now and Labour had next to nothing to say about it.But we know they’re planning to support a second referendum on the issue. Selling down the river the millions of Labour voters who thought we were best out of the European Union.At first, Labour — with great principle — stuck to the decision of the referendum.Not now they see a chance of power, the prospect of hoovering up all those votes from Remainers who think we got it wrong two years ago. There is great inequality in our country. Low wages and poor standards of living in many parts. We need a Labour Party that will support the working class ­— and lay the bloody wind turbines and their horrible Palestinian flags to one side.Not a chance.They will enter the next election as a Marxist fringe, frantically virtue-signalling to all and sundry.The Labour Party I once loved is dead.DAME JUDI DENCH has been sticking up for the “disgraced” actor, Kevin Spacey.She described him as a friend and said it was ridiculous to cut him out of films.That was brave of her. And of course she’s getting all sorts of flak from social media.Spacey has been accused of many things, all of which he denies. Nothing has been proven. But the man is now a pariah in Hollywood, even so.Well done to our finest actress for supporting America’s finest actor of the past 30 years.NOT a nice thing to say, I know. But I’ve got to admit it. Meghan Markle is beginning to get on my t*ts.One minute she’s gushing about how the kitchen set up by Grenfell Tower survivors is the true picture of Britain. . And portraying herself as being a kind of superannuated Mother Theresa, agonising over poverty.Next she’s wearing a £3,000 outfit partying with celebs in Amsterdam.I’ve said it before and I’ll say it again. Be wary of taking advice on social justice from someone whose wedding dress cost 200,000 quid.Marks &amp Spencer does one for £69, off the peg.GARY LINEKER has been leading a bunch of slebs moaning about their kids being given too much homework. Let the little children be free to play and gambol!I seem to remember Gary being very hacked off about the posh school he sent his son to. He complained that despite all the money he’d paid, the kidleft with useless grades.There’s a lesson for you in there, some- where, Gary,  you can work out what it is.She doesn’t like the way British news- papers are reporting our Brexit negotiations. So she’s called for closer “regulation” of what we can and can’t say.You’d think, being a Czech, that Vera might have had enough of Stalinism and the repression of free speech.But then she’s an EU commissioner, and that stuff sort of goes hand in hand.A FAIRLY minxy Russian chick has been spraying bleach on the groins of male passengers on the Moscow underground.She accuses them of “manspreading”. This is when blokes sit with their legs wide apart and invade the space of the next passenger.I don’t much like the habit either. But I have not yet been tempted to burn their genitals off with a toxic substance.And what about womanspreading? I was sat next to a lass on the Jubilee line last week who was the size of a dumper truck. I had my nose buried in the rolls of fat beneath her armpit.Maybe I should have got my bleach out. And while women don’t usually sit with their legs apart – unless they’ve had a few – there’s always their BAGS to contend with.THE contestants on The Apprentice were always arrogant gob-merchants with the business nous of a bowl of oxtail soup.That’s what makes the show so entertaining.But this latest lot seem – as Lord Sugar worried – in it only for the fame of being on TV.This is an example of what we will call “The Joey Essex Curve”. It’s a line on a graph. A line which descends very rapidly.The rule behind this line is simple. No matter how halutin and sensible a reality show starts out, by season five every contestant will have the IQ of Joey Essex.Then the line flattens out because you can’t get any lower.I’M very impressed by this three breasts business. Can’t have too much of a good thing.Trouble is, for obvious reasons, this new fashion is confined to women.So how about we start pioneering a trend in having four testicles? Rather than the normal two?I think that would be a winner. You could use them as a Newton’s Cradle when you were bored, such as on a long journey on public transport.The Newton’s Cradle was an executive toy from the Seventies. Lt one ball up and it smashed into the others, causing the one on the far end to move. Hours of fun in your trousers.LOOK at this poor jackass. title: homework works parents help
story: He thinks he is stupid and that little Amy is clever because she knows all the answers.What he doesn’t realise is that Amy does her homework with her family every night.American comedian Rob Delaney ignited a lively debate when he tweeted: “Why do they give seven-year-olds so much homework in the UK and how do I stop this?I want my kid frolicking and drawing and playing football.”Fellow celebrities Gary Lineker and Jason Manford agreed.Piers Morgan disagreed, calling the arguments “lazy parenting”.I have to disagree too with Mr Delaney and his supporters.Homework is essential for a child’s education because revisiting the day’s learning is what helps to make it stick.So Catastrophe star Rob and Gary Lineker are wrong in attacking compulsory home-work in primary schools.Sure, you’ll get the odd exceptionally bright pupil who will excel just through what she learns at school, despite not having that support at home.But this is very rare.Teaching is not just the teacher’s job.It takes a village to raise a child.Children learn all the time and the environment surrounding them determines how much they learn.Genes play a part in how clever a child is, but how hard they work also matters.Work hard and you’ll learn lots.Work less and you’ll learn less.Don’t make the mistake of thinking homework is for a child to do on their own.When parents use homework to bond and learn together with their child, the child understands that Mum and Dad value learning.And because a child wants to please their parents, the child’s interest in their home-work will grow, year on year.These children can see the benefit of homework and will enjoy doing it because it makes them feel better about themselves.Everyone loves to feel successful.Ten years ago, author Malcolm Gladwell introduced the idea that it takes 10,000 hours of practice to become an expert in something.We get better at what we practise, whether it’s football or maths.Our brains have a working memory and a long-term memory.If your times tables are stored in your long-term memory, you will quickly be able to calculate what it will cost to buy 12 apples instead of two.If that knowledge isn’t there, you’ll have to resort to counting on your fingers.The more knowledge stored in long-term memory, the better equipped you’ll be to think imaginatively and solve complex problems.Homework revisits what you learn at school to cement it into your long-term memory.I do agree that some home-work is pointless.Silly craft projects that involve gluing things together, which the parent will inevitably end up doing, hold no value for me.I also understand why some parents don’t like homework — they feel that it’s a battle.Parenting is hard.I get that.But we need to stop thinking of homework as a chore that the child is sent off to do, cutting into the parent’s precious time with them.It shouldn’t be the case on Sunday night that Mum says: “Oh God, it’s homework time — let’s get it over with.”Instead, learning should be part of daily le, and an enriching time for both the parent and the child.Reading with your child for 20 minutes should not be a chore.Asking them to count peas on their plate should not be hard work.While you’re out in the street, talk to them about the world around them.This is the sort of homework that is often set for very young children and it can be done without making it feel like a formal lesson.It doesn’t need to be half an hour sitting at a desk.It can just be ten minutes of enjoyable time together.Homework can be written down but can also be spoken or done online, leaving little marking for the teacher.Secondary-school homework can help you learn with your child.You can learn some French again or be reminded of the beauty of Shakespeare!How wonderful is that?By scaffolding the support at home, you can gradually wean them off it, just like taking off bike stabilisers.Eventually, they learn to work independently, so that when they get to GCSEs, they will be in the habit of doing their homework each night.If you don’t get them into the homework habit from an early age, you risk having a battle with a stroppy teen as they approach their exams.And no parent wants that.Those who are against homework will argue that their children have no time for other hobbies.This is nonsense.Children generally finish school at 3.15pm, and younger ones tend to go to bed at about 8pm.That’s nearly five hours of free time.Are they really spending it playing hockey or going to Brownies?I doubt it.Half an hour of homework in five hours of spare time is a drop in the ocean, leaving lots of time for other things.The real worry for parents should be how much time children are spending on social media — something that is so very dangerous and takes up hours of their time, unlike homework.Katharine Birbalsingh is head of Michaela Community School, North London, and has been dubbed the country’s “strictest head teacher”.She introduced an ultra-disciplined approach to learning called Tiger Teaching.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun says jeremy corbyn speech
story: It was his traditional blend of bile, fantasy and lies, falteringly recited in his two stock voices — all hammily-acted phoney compassion one moment, ­sudden exaggerated rage the next.He turned his ire first on Tories, then on a critical Press. This, he insisted, would remain free under Labour — but not just to print what it liked. Thick as he is, ­Corbyn sees no contradiction.Then it was on to Jezza curing all our ills with freebies galore and mass job creation, all presumably funded by the same tax on the rich. Since Labour aides now privately admit their 2017 manesto secretly covered up a £1TRILLION bill, Corbyn’s assurances aren’t worth the autocue they are written on.This smug, cocky Labour conference is an annual reminder of just what a dishonest rabble they now are. Sickeningly posing as defenders of the dispossessed while plotting to annul their Brexit votes with a second referendum, brought about by orchestrating chaos.One moronic MP even demanded a General Strike to oust the Government. Frontbencher Richard Burgon stood and applauded. And he is the “next Secretary of State for Justice”, God help us.Corbyn is keen to rebrand his extremism as mainstream in an era when capitalism has “failed”. It is, in reality, a dog-eared hard-left roadmap to ruin on a scale we have never experienced.A Britain which would kill ambition and enterprise and drive out successful firms by stealing their property. Where investors would fear to tread and from which anyone who could would flee.Labour’s candidate for PM is a dim, vain, vindictive, unapologetically anti­-Semitic ball of rage who loathes scrutiny, lies habitually about his true beliefs and past terrorist connections and is, his aides admit, “not good in the mornings”.But the Tories must not mistake all that for a free pass. Corbyn’s plans have traction only because the Government has left the battlefield.Theresa May and Philip Hammond are timid tinkerers when we need radical steps to put more money in pockets and make homes affordable. Socialism is the last thing we need. Next to last are Tory “Corbyn-lite” tax rises.Record job figures, low inflation and interest rates add up to a society and economy far healthier than the dystopia of chippy Corbynite imaginations.But  the Tories don’t fix the problems that DO exist they’re sunk, and Britain too.WELL done to Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson for swtly ensuring the kids of dying RAF officer Samantha McConnell will not be denied her pension.Now he must change the rules for good.So others like her get the same deal.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
