title: gay penguins kidnap chick from straight parents at denmark zoo
story: Apparently the drama unfolded in a zoo in Denmark when the chick’s mum and dad were having their daily paddle.Animal keeper Sandie Hedegård Munck told Danish broadcaster DR the male penguin couple at Odense Zoo have been desperate to become parents.So, she claims when they saw the chick being “neglected” by its parents, they decided to intervene and snatch it in hope of adopting it.Sandie said: I could see that something was completely wrong. The parents disappeared and the kid was simply kidnapped. It was a pair of gay males who had snatched it and was stood with it.”Sandie said she believed the mum had gone for her daily bath and when she did not  in time for the dad appeared to have forgotten all about his parental responsibilities and left the baby alone.She added: “When they saw him alone they probably thought ‘that’s too bad, we’ll snatch it.It was thought the mum and dad would  and claim their chick back, but that did not immediately happen.  Eventually they did come looking for it and it was decided to give them custody of the bird.Seemingly scandalised by the sight, the Edwardian scientist described the behaviour as depraved. More recently the behaviour has been observed in a number of zoos. In 2014 Jumbs and Hurricane, two Humboldt penguins at Wingham Wildle Park in Kent became inseparable and became celebrities in their own right.They later successfully hatched and reared an egg given to them as surrogate parents after the mum abandoned it halfway through incubation.At first the flightless, two-toned fellas got in a flap about giving up their adopted child without a fight, but Sandie said with a heavy heart they eventually let go.But while this may pull at heartstrings, there is a happy ending to the story because the zookeepers, after seeing how they cared for the baby, have decided to give them an egg from a new mum who was unable to look after her offspring because of illness.

title: mum baby decapitated botched birth doctor said ive fixed him
story: Laura Gallazzi was 25 weeks pregnant when she went into labour, with a top NHS doctor pulling the babys legs during the birth.But the babys head was detached from his body during the horric delivery, with his head still left in his mothers womb.The first-time mum was then forced to undergo a C-section to remove the head - which was sewn back on to the tragic tots body so she could hold him and say goodbye.Cradling the plush bear that holds her sons ashes, the mum revealed to BBC Radio Scotland her terror at seeing her sons body, unsure what she would be confronted with.She said: I thought I dont want to see him, dont bring him in here, because I didnt know what I was going to be looking at.The doctor said its alright. Her words were Ive fixed him.Since a tribunal into the 2014 delivery at Dundees Ninewells hospital in Dundee, Scotland, Laura has spoken out of how she could not forgive the consultant gynaecologist, Dr Vaishnavy Laxman, for Stevens death.The investigation found that while Dr Laxmans decision to proceed with a vaginal delivery instead of a C-section was a mistake, the medic was cleared to  to work.Traumatised Laura, 34, earlier told The Sun: She butchered my son. How could this happen in this day and age?”Only three babies in the world are known to have succumbed to such a sickening fate and Laura said: It’s like something from medieval times. I never imagined this would be my experience of birth.”Dr Laxman admitted she had tried “too hard” to deliver the tot and the tribunal said she had been wrong not to carry out the initial C-section. But it ruled the senior gynaecologist had been working in the “best interests” of the mum, and that she posed “no risk to patient safety”.The ordeal has taken a huge toll on haunted Laura who now suffers post-traumatic stress disorder.The mum now keeps Stevens ashes in a teddy so she can have him with her — and on her forearm has tattoo prints of his hands and feet as well as the roman numerals of the year he was born.She says: “Even though I wasn’t ever able to hold him, I can carry him with me wherever I go now. Where I go, the teddy goes. I draw enormous comfort from it and would be lost without it.”

title: jeremy corbyn michel barnier brussels brexit
story: The Labour leaders aide had to make an urgent appeal for cash after realising no one was able to pay for the cab in Brussels this afternoon.Mr Corbyn was left waiting outside EU headquarters as his staff had a whip-round - and risked being late for his meeting with top eurocrat Michel Barnier.He told Mr Barnier, the EUs Brexit envoy, that Britain cant quit the EU without a trade deal lined up.The talks are a fresh bid to undermine the official Brexit negotiations being carried out by Theresa May.Mr Corbyn drew up at the office of the European Commission in a taxi with Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer.But the driver apparently refused to go in to the buildings vehicle entrance until he was paid - and he didnt accept cards.A Labour aide was heard asking, Does anyone have any euros?Mr Corbyns right-hand man Seumas Milne laughed as another aide stepped in to provide the money needed.Labours fresh attempt to sideline Mrs May in Brussels comes after Labour opened the door to a second referendum on Brexit at their party conference this week.Mr Corbyn took Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer with him on the trip to Brussels today.Speaking after the meting, he said: Weve had an interesting, useful discussion with Mr Barnier.We have set out the views of the Labour Party surrounding Brexit following the conference speeches made by Keir Starmer and myself.We are obviously not negotiating. We are not in government, we are the opposition. But he was interested to know what our views are and the six tests we have laid down by which we will hold our government in future.The Labour boss refused to say whether Mr Barnier had backed Labours plan - which would keep the UK in the European customs union - over Theresa Mays.He said it would be going over the line to press the eurocrat on his views.Mr Corbyn said last night: “Crashing out of Europe with no deal risks being a national disaster.That is why I’m meeting EU officials today, and I will be urging them to do all they can to avoid a No Deal outcome, which would be so damaging to jobs and living standards in both the UK and EU countries.”The PM has repeatedly insisted that Britain must be prepared for a No Deal scenario.Otherwise the EU will be able to force us to accept whatever deal they want.Mr Corbyn is keen to keep Britain in the European customs union after Brexit - even though that would stop us cutting trade deals around the world.And at the Labour conference, activists voted for a new policy which could see the party backing a second referendum  Mrs May refuses to hold a General Election.Mr Barnier has previously met with a string of pro-EU politicians from Britain, who have lobbied him not to accept the PMs Brexit plans.

title: man makes mistake girlfriends moonpig card
story: Ryan Smith assured girlfriend Laura McKay he had made her a good one this year after she complained about him sending her cards late on her past two birthdays.The lad spent time adding in lots of personal snaps of the couples relationship together into a collage on the card companys website.But when long-suffering Laura opened up the card she was surprised to find it addressed to Georgia.Ryan - who Laura admits lacks common sense - had forgotten to change the template name on the card from Georgia to Laura.Laura thought shed missed a joke and asked: Are you kidding?Laura eventually understood what had happened - and found it so funny she called her mum in to have a look.Speaking to Unilad, Laura said: He does try his best with absolutely everything but sometimes his lack of common sense gets in the way.This is the most him thing possible. He was so excited to give me the card and it was just so funny because he tried so hard. I couldn’t even be angry at him.I shouted my mum in and told her about it and she couldn’t stop laughing.It’s up on my window ledge because I love the pictures on it.Ryans mum had even warned her son to check the card before handing it over.Laura said: He hands me it in the same envelope that it got delivered to his house in – even though it comes with two as you’re meant to open it, CHECK IT and put it in a fresh envelope.Might I add when it got delivered to his house, his mum said to him maybe you should check it but he was adamant it was perfect.”Laura should count herself lucky that it was her and Ryan’s faces smiling back from the card and not a photo of his genitals.Moonpig yesterday told customers to stop uploading pictures of their private parts and sending them in to be made into customised cards.

title: theresa may conservative party capitalism
story: In an astonishing eve of party conference blast, Sam Gymiah said the Government had to offer a compelling capitalist vision to voters and stop trying to “out-Corbyn, Corbyn”.The Minister – who sits in both the Departments for Education and Business – stormed: “whichever side you are on in the Brexit debate, we need to realise that  we are not the party of business then we are nothing.”Speaking to House magazine, Mr Gyimah said that the Tories had been wrong to try and respond to Labour’s rhetoric.He said the Government gave the impression of “wanting to take on the mantle of Trumpian economic nationalism and protectionism”.And he instead urged Theresa May to align with business, and “make the case for reinvigorating capitalism”.“When we Conservatives veer between talking business down, ignoring voters’ concerns, and telling businesses to shut up – or worse – it is clear sign we have lost our way,” he said.The attack came just hours after former Minister Rob Halfon urged Theresa May to take notice of the “serious” offer from Labour – and do more for Britain’s struggling workers.It follows a spate of similar high-profile attacks from rising Tories such as Treasury Minister Liz Truss and Tory deputy chair James Cleverly.Ms Truss used a speech in the US earlier this month to insist the Tories stop “apologising for backing enterprise”.Mr Cleverly last week urged the party to give the public “something positive” to vote for.Theresa May has slapped a price cap on the energy sector as part of a campaign to fix “broken markets”.And ex-Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson sparked uproar in the summer after it emerged he snapped “f***” business in a rant at the CBI over Brexit.In his article, Mr Gyimah stormed: “When it comes to our relationship with business, we must unscramble our compass  we are to stand any chance of defeating the hard left.”He added: “We need to be honest about the failings of capitalism, while making the case that it’s the best system we’ve got. Attacking Labour and proclaiming our sound economic management is necessary but not sufficient.“I can’t help thinking we have lost our way. Disconcerted by a sht in the zeitgeist against business, and by the cumulative surprises of the financial crisis, the EU referendum and the 2017 general election, we appear to have become confused about how to handle business.“We are at our best when we are pro-enterprise and pro-endeavour, and when we do this in a way that is clear that our motive is to make the world a better place and improve the lot of ordinary citizens.“To succeed we need to offer a compelling alternative vision that the next generation can buy into.“We can’t out-Corbyn Corbyn, and  we try, we risk offering a pale imitation that leaves people yearning for the real thing.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: renters abandon tories housing
story: A new survey of the 60 tighest constituency battlefields shows barely a quarter – 28% - of the key voting group living in them now back Theresa May’s party. Half – 50% - now plan to vote for Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour party instead.The findings – by pollsters Number Cruncher Politics for the housing charity Shelter – suggest soaring rents and sky high house prices are now an even bigger issue in deciding who will run the country than at the last general election.The poll also reveals that Labour has now leapfrogged the Tories to take a 2 point lead in the marginals among all voters, by 42% v 40%.That reverses the result at last year’s general election where the Tories narrowly came out on top across the 60 tightest races, by 46% v 44% - meaning the party has shed six per of its support in 16 months.All voters in the marginals say they are also now more pessimistic about the state of housing than any other issue.Two thirds of them - 67% - think the cost and availability of housing has got worse over the past five years.In comparison the number worried about rising crime is 66%, those troubled by falling healthcare standards , rising immigration levels , and the poorer quality of schools .Private renters also back an increase in the number of council houses being built over policies to help with homeownership, the poll also found.A total of 39% of them in the marginal said the government should prioritise building more social housing, compared to only 31% who preferred controversial schemes such as Help to Buy.Number Cruncher Politics’s boss Matt Singh said: “Housing was key to last year’s general election result, with renters – and particularly private renters – fuelling the increase in turnout and swing to Labour that cost the Conservatives their majority.“The poll shows that housing is both important to voters in crucial marginal seats, and something they feel particularly gloomy about.“These findings sound a warning to the Tories ahead of their conference.”In what experts dubbed a ‘rentquake’, there was a huge boost in turnout among enraged private renters at the nationwide poll last year.Three in ten renters who voted Tory in 2015 – 29% - abandoned the party in 2017, with three-quarters of them defecting to Labour.Shelter CEO Polly Neate said the research should “set alarm bells ringing for MPs”.Ms Neate added: “Key voters are very pessimistic about the housing crisis, and private renters in particular look like they pose a threat at the ballot box. But there are options on the table to get out of this mess.“As the numbers show, instead of pumping more cash into failed ideas like Help to Buy, we should be building much more social housing to give hard-pressed families an alternative to the private rented sector.“Not only would this be a massive stride towards ending this crisis, but it’d be wildly popular too – so let’s get on with it.”Between 2001 and 2018 the size of the private rental sector doubled, from 11% of the adult population to 28%.The same period also saw a marked decline in the number who own their own home, falling from 73% of the population to 59%.The Tories are consumed by Brexit. But away from that they must wake up and present radical ideas to beat ­Corbyn’s, especially on housing.They have an advantage.Theirs are more likely to be sane.And vanishingly less likely to put hundreds of thousands on the dole.But Theresa May must realise that voters have more pressing problems than Brexit which could cost her power.Next week the Tories must have a new story to tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pm nypd aides stranded
story: The PM’s  flight from the UN General Assembly in the Big Apple was delayed by an hour due to the hiccup.Eleven senior advisors were travelling in a bus in the PM’s motorcade to JFK airport when its gear box packed up.The bus was stuck blocking two lanes of traffic for about half an hour before a replacement bus was found.And three police officers in a NYPD squad car escorted them to the airport.But the PM made them sweat by pretending to set a six-minute deadline to arrive - otherwise she would order the pilot to take off without them.Her chief of joined in - telling them take-off was imminent.The top aides - who included deputy national security advisor Christian Turner, head of operations Richard Tricky” Jackson and her senior spin doctors - were already looking up alternative flights home.But Mrs May welcomed them onto the plane in person when they arrived nearly an hour later than her - and led a round of applause.She invited the three NYPD police officers up the steps for a photo.A Downing Street source said: “New York’s finest rescued the PM’s team from the side of the freeway and got us to the runway for the flight home. “Just another way to deepen the special relationship, and we’re very grateful for their help.”The bus broke down while travelling in the fast lane as part of the PM’s motorcade from downtown Manhattan to JFK airport.Cars were flying by at speeds of more than 40mph. One of the aides said: “It was pretty hairy stuff.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: motor groups argue fuel duty hike
story: FairFuelUK will meet Treasury Secretary Robert Jenrick on October 9 – amid fears the Chancellor is about to rubber stamp the first increase in the tax for EIGHT YEARS.It comes as sources claim hauliers are preparing to “drive on Parliament” in protest at sky-high petrol prices.Separately, new figures from FairFuel show that struggling Brits are spending up to 25 per cent of their hard-earned cash on filling up their car.Nearly 4 per cent of Brits on £25,000 spend 25 per cent or more on petrol, while nearly a third spend between 15-25 per cent.Other findings from the poll of 71,000 motorists show that 67 per cent of people have “categorically no choice” but to use their car every day.Speaking last night, FairFuel UK co-founder Howard Cox said: “It’s time the Treasury listened to the ‘just about managing’ and got in touch with reality.“Don’t hit those in the pocket who will decide the next Government.It would be political suicide.”Fuel duty has been frozen ever since the Sun’s ‘Keep it Down’ campaign launched in Spring 2011.Chancellor Philip Hammond on Wednesday announced this year’s Budget willtake place on October 29. The early date means it can take place before any potential row with Eurosceptics over the Brexit deal with Brussels.Speaking last month, the Chancellorover the rest of the decade could generate an extra £38 billion for the Treasury.Fuel duty in the UK is among the highest in Europe, at nearly 60p of the pump price.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: beluga whale thames stay months
story: The Beluga, which is normally used to swimming in Arctic waters, was first spotted on Tuesday morning between Gravesend and Tilbury in the River Thames.British Divers Marine Le Rescue Director Geoff Hammock and Thames region coordinator Sam Lipman used a Rigid Inflatable Boat  to get close to the Beluga whale.Mr Hammock said: It is as well as can be expected.We think it is feeding.He added: “We think that  there was not any food it would have been looking for food.It keeps coming back to the same point.But Ms Lipman said the whale could stay in the Thames “for weeks or months  he or she is happy feeding.”She added: We are looking at body condition and behaviour.We are just going on what we can observe.It looks like it could be a sub-adult, it has grey tinges.There have only been about 20 reports in British waters so it is a really rare occurrence.The whale, which is believed to be up to three metres long, was spotted at 10:30am on the Kent side on Thursday morning.Richard Sabin, a whale expert from Londons Natural History Museum, previously said: Belugas eat a wide iety of prey and this will increase this animals survival chances.”Its good news he appears to be feeding well because he will stand a greater chance of ing north to his normal habitat  he can stay strong.A spokesman for ORCA added: “The experts on the ground are monitoring closely and  the situation changes plans are in place to respond quickly and effectively.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Bearded Duerte Xavier, 33, allegedly lured them with female images then arranged blindfolded romps by phone.He performed a sex act on one before intercourse in a park, it was said.The man told how Xavier’s phone voice “sounded feminine and Asian”.He said of their meeting: “I put my scarf around my head and waited.Then it went to taking my trousers down.“I made attempts to touch her, which were thwarted.”The man said the ten-minute act “seemed quite pleasant” before 20 minutes of full sex.He was told to stay blindfolded until Xavier left, Kingston crown court, South West London, heard.Xavier met another man at a local flat after luring him on app Lovoo and WhatsApp, it was said.One Xavier message allegedly demanded: “Be my obedient toy.”As the man headed to the address, Xavier allegedly sent a picture of a blindfolded guy receiving a sex act — an instruction to his victim.The man was buzzed into the flat and told to don a mask before Xavier appeared.The man said: “I wanted to see.I pulled it down and saw this man with a beard.I felt p***** off and slapped him.”The man left but Xavier pestered him to meet again, it was said.The man called police.Xavier, of Bournemouth, denies six charges of causing a person to engage in sex without consent.The trial continues.GOT a story? title: pizza express kitchen no vegan cheese
story: Mary Nesbitt-Larking was at the branch in Hatfield, Hertfordshire when she opted for the vegan offering.What came out of the kitchen has been rightfully described as a “shameful monstrosity” after it emerged that the restaurant had run out of its supply of vegan cheese.In her photograph, the thin pizza base is seen topped with lashings of thick red tomato sauce, and just a handful of red onions.In a previous visit to the same outlet, she had been served a vegan pizza with vegan mozzarella, spinach, red onions and caramelised onions – a far cry from what she had in front of her that day.Within minutes of her posting the sad image online, she was inundated with comments, with many asking  it was a “bad joke”.One wrote: “OMG what haw can they have the cheek to serve you this mess of a pizza I would of refuse to have it Mary I’m so sorry hun that is shameful disgusting they could of made it better put peppers olives chilliest pineapple something to make it look nice.Another outraged friend wrote: “Are you serious. What an insult. Did you throw it at them ??!!While some of her pals though the pizza “looked funny”, others branded it a “monstrosity” and were outraged that she was charged £9 for it.Speaking to Femail, Mary said: “Vegan food options are amazing, and Pizza Express are incredible usually, it was just that one time they failed so epically.“It was so awkward because Id waited over an hour and at that point I would have eaten anything as long as it was vegan.“It tasted like undercooked flat bread with a whole tin of tomatoes over it that were really sour, and had raw, red onions on top.”Mary, who went vegan more than five years ago, managed to keep a sense of humour about the incident, uploading the image with a laughing emoji and facepalm emoji.The restaurant has since apologised to Mary for letting her down and have invited her back to try their new autumn menu, with a dedicated vegan section, as a way to say sorry.

title: jeremy corbyn leave betray class
story: If selling out Leave voters doesn’t bother you then yes, Michel Barnier and Martin Selmayr — the German bully running the show — will delightedly hear how you intend to achieve it.Which explains why they were so keen to give him an audience yesterday.Betrayal is very much in Corbyn’s plans, as he made clear at his conference.Not only because his party is now firmly behind a second referendum with “Remain” as one of the options.But because he is also determined to stay in the EU’s Customs Union — and thus not leave at all.So, in the unthinkable event of a Labour Government seeing Brexit through, it would do so not via tough negotiations.It would be done by immediate capitulation to Brussels’ demands that the world’s fth biggest economy remain forever under their control.We would be barred in perpetuity from signing trade deals with the faster-growing giant economies of the wider world — and the central economic case for Brexit would be destroyed.So while Corbyn now suddenly claims to care for the forgotten working-class communities who backed Leave, they must never forget this: Labour is now controlled by its middle-class London Remainer membership, all desperate to overturn or negate Brexit.WE’LL be blunt, Becks.It is repugnant to see a celebrity smugly dodge justice solely thanks to being rich enough for a fancy lawyer skilled at exploiting loopholes.Especially when that star freely admits doing 59mph in a 40 zone.Millions of ordinary people grimly suck up fines they can ill afford for far lesser speeding offences.Even  their prosecution letter arrives a day late.Beckham may be within the letter of the law, but not its spirit.That’s a bad look for a man desperate for public adulation and establishment approval.Knighthood? It’s crashed and burned.WE hope the poll revealing voters in ­marginal seats deserting the Tories over sky-high rents is enough to stir the ­Government from its paralysis.The Tories are consumed by Brexit.But away from that they must wake up and present radical ideas to beat ­Corbyn’s, especially on housing.They have an advantage.Theirs are more likely to be sane.And vanishingly less likely to put hundreds of thousands on the dole.But Theresa May must realise that voters have more pressing problems than Brexit which could cost her power.Next week the Tories must have a new story to tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gp surgery shutdown catastrophic

title: david beckham nick freeman mr loophole speeding
story: The footie star admitted driving at nearly 60mph in a 40mph zone - but avoided punishment because prosecutors sent him notice of the offence a day late.His lawyer Nick Freeman - dubbed Mr Loophole for his track record of getting celebs out of trouble - said that from a moral standpoint Becks should have been found guilty.And he called on the Government to change the law which lets speeding drivers escape justice because of minor errors by the prosecution.Mr Freeman told the BBCs Today programme: It was made quite clear from the very start that Mr Beckham didnt dispute that he was speeding.Anyone who accepts that they were the driver and they were speeding, you would think in the normal course from a moral standpoint they should be convicted.But  the law of the land, the law laid down by our Government says no actually...The lawyer insisted the case would help the public by making people more aware of the laws they can use to dodge speeding fines.But he added that MPs should vote to close the loophole  they want to bring more rogue drivers to justice.Mr Freeman said: What Parliament needs to do is it needs to change the law.And he also took a dig at prosecutors - suggesting they were targeting Mr Beckham because of his fame and saying an ordinary Joe or ordinary Jane would never have been taken to court.The former England captain was caught doing 59mph in a 40mph at the wheel of a £200,000 Bentley in January this year.But the notice that hed be prosecuted didnt arrive until 15 days after the offence took place - one day after the two-week deadline.Mr Freeman convinced a judge to throw out the case because of the blunder, leaving Mr Beckham very relieved.Road safety campaigners blasted the verdict and said the football legend should have set a better example.

title: derek hatton inspired jeremy corbyn
story: NewsDerek Hatton says he's rejoined Labour Party 33 years after he was booted outThe firebrand says he has no aim to stand for office despite his new affiliationShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByGavin AllenAssociate EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor01:13, 28 SEP 2018Updated08:37, 28 SEP 2018NewsDerek Hatton has been a long time away from membership of the Labour party "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDerek Hatton has said he has rejoined the Labour Party - 33 years after he was booted out by then-leader Neil Kinnock. Mr Hatton, former deputy leader of Liverpool's City Council, was expelled for belonging to the left-wing Militant faction. He caused national outcry in the 1980s by setting an illegal budget and was denounced for sending redundancy notices by taxi to thousands of council workers. He and other members of Trotskyite group known as the Militant Tendency were widely blamed for making the party unelectable during Mr Kinnock's tenure. The 70-year-old former poster boy of the hard left has said he was inspired by Jeremy Corbyn's leadership to reapply for membership. Despite Mr Hatton telling the Liverpool Echo he has rejoined the party, it is understood he is not currently a member. However, it is thought party chiefs are not aware of anything in Labour rules that will bar him from rejoining.   Just days ago a shadow cabinet minister, Jon Ashworth, dismissed reports Mr Hatton could rejoin saying: He does this all the time, doesn't he? He's not going to join the Labour Party. He just does this for publicity. Writing in the Echo, Mr Hatton said he spent much of the last 33 years at odds with the Labour leadership, particular at Tony Blair's decision to invade Iraq. However, he said he had remained committed to the party throughout the period and this week's Labour conference had prompted him to rejoin. Former Labour leader Neil Kinnock booted Mr Hatton out of the party after giving one of the most famous conference speeches in history. The 1985 address declaring war on Militant was hailed by Mr Kinnock's supporters as the turning point in the battle to purge the hard left from Labour. Mr Kinnock told the party faithful: “I’ll tell you what happens with impossible promises. You start with far-fetched resolutions.  They are then pickled into a rigid dogma, a code, and you go through the years sticking to that, out-dated, mis-placed, irrelevant to the real needs, and you end in the grotesque chaos of a Labour council – a Labour council! - hiring taxis to scuttle round a city handing out redundancy notices to its own workers. As he spoke, Mr Hatton shouted: Liar! This week, Mr Hatton hailed a sea change under unswerving socialist Mr Corbyn - saying he never dreamed a backer of mass nationalisation would lead the Labour Party.  [His] leader’s speech made me say something I never thought I’d say: We have a ‘socialist Prime Minister in waiting’, he said.  He also hit out over the party's anti-Semitism row, saying it was disgraceful that Chuka Umunna called Labour institutionally racist.  He wrote: In all my time I have never witnessed such passion, such energy and such powerful socialist leadership. And strangely that power is despite a kinder, gentler form of politics. Many people, myself included, probably never thought we would witness an unswerving socialist like Jeremy Corbyn at the helm.

title: inside britains only youth foodbank
story: NewsInside Britain's only youth foodbank: The girl left homeless when her dad was murdered and the hungry young people whose shoes are falling offWe visited Britain's only 'youth foodbank', located in Liverpool just 15 minutes from the Labour Party conferenceShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist17:36, 27 SEP 2018Updated19:04, 27 SEP 2018NewsLuise Watson, an intensive mentor at the Merseyside youth food bank "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAbout 15 minutes’ walk from where Labour conference met this week in Liverpool is Britain’s only ‘youth foodbank’. “Lots of young people in the city were telling us they felt bad when they went to a foodbank and saw families with young children there,” says Merseyside Youth &shyAssociation’s Luise Watson. “They didn’t think they deserved it. Or they didn’t want to take food from the children.” MYA’s response was to develop its own service for young people aged 16-25. This week, I took one of those young people – Stacey Bridge – to the Labour conference to speak alongside our other guests, including her childhood hero, the former Everton goalkeeping legend Neville Southall. Over 250 people came to hear them. “The first day I went to the foodbank I thought it would be really horrible,” says Stacey, who now volunteers at MYA and is enrolled in one of its youth programmes. I expected to be really embarrassed and they’d just give you a bag of food. It’s the opposite. You get so much help and support. When I left I actually felt really good.”  Stacey, now 26, had been left homeless after struggling to pay for her dad’s funeral following his murder. “We were down to a bottle of juice and half a loaf of bread when we came in. I was living in a hostel with my partner who was on a low wage working as a chef.” Before that she’d had several nights at a ‘sit up’ service, where there are no beds provided. Stacey now helps at the foodbank where “you see young people come in and their shoes are falling off them”, she says. “You can tell how hungry they are.” I first met Stacey a few weeks ago in Liverpool, and asked her  she’d come to speak at Labour conference – joining Amina Weston, a young woman who was &shyillegally evicted when she was pregnant, and Southall, who now works with excluded kids. I wanted them to remind the conference that every day without a change in government is a lost day for millions of young people. It’s another day hungry. Another day homeless. Another day of a baby brought up in bed and breakfast. Amina, from Leeds, who I met through our Wigan Pier Project, read a poem at our fringe meeting that left some delegates, including Unite leader Len McCluskey, in tears.  “Bedroom floors, sofas, dispersed hostels and bidding numbers,” she read. “What a le for a little baby.” Homelessness meant Amina was forced to give up on her third year of university. Yet she has still gone on to set up a school unorm project with her sister to help struggling families. “It makes you realise what we’re about,” McCluskey said. “We’re about fighting for fairness, for decency, for justice for all people.” Neville Southall spoke about desperately trying to get help for his foster sons and for the excluded kids he now works with. “The education system is a nightmare at the moment,” he said. Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell praised our Wigan Pier Project and said that George Orwell had taught in his constituency. The 1984 author had been senior master at the former Hawthorns High School for Boys in the early 1930s, before he left for Wigan.  “If George Orwell came back to my constituency today, he’d find families living in beds in sheds and garages,” McDonnell said in a blistering speech. “We’ve got people living in vans and cars. We’ve reinvented the back-to-back in my constituency – where one family lives in the rear of the property and one in the front. “We’ve got people sleeping in our parks, along the canal and under bridges on a scale we’ve not seen before. Five thousand of our fellow &shycitizens are out there sleeping on the streets tonight. That’s a bloody disgrace in the sixth richest country in the world. “If George Orwell came back today he’d know what zero-hours was like. Because on these docks just down here my dad and my granddad used to line up in the street in the 1930s and they’d be pointed at  they’d got work and  they didn’t they’d be sent home. “That’s what’s happening with zero-hour contracts given to our kids in 2018.”

title: jeremy corbyns economic medicine looks
story: NewsopinionJeremy Corbyn's economic medicine looks increasingly attractiveThe Labour leader promised to transform a country still reeling from the financial crash. And his plans are chiming with the public moodShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics13:52, 26 SEP 2018NewsopinionJeremy Corbyn reached out to Brexit voters in his speech "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn today gave a speech that has been a decade in the making. This was an address to a country which is still suffering ten years after the financial crash. His plans are bold but his pitch was simple: only Labour has the policies which will mend the damage caused by the banking crisis and the subsequent Tory austerity. Labour, he declared, is now the new majority whose ideas have caught the mood of the time. Much of the speech was directed to those areas which voted Leave in the Brexit referendum.  Corbyn made clear he understood their motives and stood ready to help them rebuild their communities. “There will be no more left behind areas,” he said. Yet this speech was an acknowledgement that his party must do more to persuade voters it was fit to govern. First, there was an appeal to the Labour rank and file to show more unity. Divided and hate-filled parties will not win elections. Secondly, he looked to reassure people that while his agenda was radical it was also common sense. Like a kindly doctor speaking to a patient before an operation, he tried to convince them the procedure may be pioneering but was in their best interests.

title: tories spend 40000 hide how
story: NewsTories spend £40,000 to 'hide' how rarely Northern Powerhouse minister James Wharton goes up northThere were just 28 references to meetings in the North in the minister's diary, freedom of information requests have revealed after a y legal battleShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor19:27, 27 SEP 2018NewsJames Wharton's Government department took two years to answer simple questions "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Government has spent &pound40,000 of taxpayers’ cash trying to “hide” how rarely the Tory minister for the North visited the North. The Department for Communities and Local Government received a request under freedom of information laws two years ago asking how regularly James Wharton travelled outside London. The Government flouted a requirement to respond to the request within 20 working days and did not provide a response for more than four months - at which point it denied the application. The Information Commissioner’s Office subsequently launched a probe and found the Government adopted a strategy of “wilful procrastination in order to obstruct a request for information”. The DCLG appealed against the decision to the first-tier tribunal of information rights, where in early 2018 Judge Hazel Oliver ruled that the department must hand over Wharton’s diary.  The whole process took 26 months. The information - diary entries between January and April 2016 - that the Government sought to suppress for two years shows that Mr Wharton rarely left London as part of his ministerial role as the North’s representative. Of the 693 lines of entries in his ministerial diary, half have office details or identiable addresses in the “Location” column, of which 90% of them are in London. Just 28 relate to a meeting or event in the North. Mr Wharton was a Tory MP for Stockton South until he lost his seat in 2017. The Government fought for so long to prevent the release of the information that two other men, Andrew Percy and Jake Berry, have since taken up the role of Northern Powerhouse minister, and the entire department has been renamed as the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government.  Sarah Longlands, director of IPPR North, a Manchester-based think tank, said: “It is of course disappointing that the minister charged with the Northern Powerhouse spent so little time in the area getting to understand what’s important to the people, communities and businesses of the north. “But the attempts to thwart access to information about the work of the northern Powerhouse minister show a blatant disregard for the principles of democratic accountability. “The Government need to use this as an opportunity to build a much more robust system of transparency and accountability, so that voters in the north can have confidence that the government are really serious and committed to supporting northern leaders to build a better future for the north.” Legal experts also slammed the Government.

story: NewsMan finally gets 'perfect' birthday card for girlfriend - but makes worst mistake possibleHis birthday cards have been late for the last two years so he was really trying to make this one specialShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of Audience18:44, 27 SEP 2018Updated18:50, 27 SEP 2018NewsLaura wasn't very happy when she opened the card "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who sent his girlfriend birthday cards late for two years thought he'd finally produced the 'perfect' card on Moonpig - and didn't even realise his crucial mistake. title: girl 4 excluded school more
story: NewsGirl, 4, 'excluded from school more than 10 times' despite parents saying she could have autismDaniel and Gemma Cullen believe their daughter Caoimhe may have autism and think it should have been handled betterShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAbie Wightwick09:45, 28 SEP 2018Updated09:47, 28 SEP 2018NewsCaoimhe Cullen, four, may have autism and is waiting for a formal diagnosis "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOutraged parents of a four-year-old pupil claim she has been excluded more than 10 times in just over a year. Daniel and Gemma Cullen, from Rhondda in Wales believe their daughter Caoimhe may have autism and say she is waiting for a formal diagnosis. The pair say she was excluded more than 10 times in just over a year at Tylorstown Primary in Rhonnda Cynon Taf between April 2017 and July 2018, reports Wales Online . The disruption meant Gemma had to leave her job at a nursery. Now in her second year at school, Caoimhe attends one day a week and spends the other four days a week at a special educational needs class at Cwm Clydach Primary. Calling for better understanding of autism and possible autism among teachers and schools, Gemma said Caoimhe has never been allowed to take part in a school play and has been kept indoors at play-time at Tylorstown Primary. “She was suspended around times of school trips or extra curricular activities and during the National Tests,” said Gemma.  “She has had two five-day suspensions for kicking someone and has had three day suspensions and half day suspensions here and there. “We think she has autism, it is some sort of additional needs, but she is still a baby.” Daniel, 32, and Gemma, 29, say she has not yet had a statement of special educational needs, although they believe she has autism and/or other SENs. “We pushed and pushed for an educational psychologist evaluation which concluded that Caoimhe has a lot of autistic traits and is seriously sensory overwhelmed  in school where she can’t cope and recommended four day placement in a dferent, calmer setting,” her mum said. “We have contacted the GP and health visitor for referral to the neurodevelopment team [at hospital in Merthyr] and are still on the waiting list for an appointment. I would like some sort of help. “This has been so disruptive I had to leave my job because the school were phoning me every day to come and get her. I was a senior educator in a nursery, in Porth.” Gemma said she filed a complaint to the pupil discipline and exclusions committee of the governing body of Tylorstown Primary School after her daughter was excluded for five days last term. The committee, in July, upheld that exclusion but found procedures were not followed for one exclusion in 2017.  In a letter to her, dated July 10 this year, a support officer for the governors said: ”The committee considered the decision made by Mrs Tuck to exclude your daughter Caoimhe, for a five day period on 15th June 2018 and, after carefully considering the representations made and all the available evidence, have decided to uphold this exclusion. “The reasons for the committee’s decision are as follows: Members felt that the exclusion was warranted due to the fact that it was in response to serious breaches of the school’s behaviour policy and by allowing Caoimhe to stay in school would seriously harm the education/welfare of her or others in the school. “The Committee will investigate the information you were given as there seems to be some discrepancy with that and advice provided to the headteacher... “...In relation to the alleged unlawful exclusion in October 2017  governors agree that the guidance was not followed. This was acknowledged by the headteacher at the meeting.” The letter goes on to say: “The committee felt the support and level of graduated response that has been put in place by the school over a long period of time for Caoimhe and, plans for her future via a four day placement in the Nurture Class in Cwmclydach Primary School were sufficient, and hope that she settles in well. Because the five-day exclusion in June was a fixed term exclusion of less than 15 days, the Cullens were told they had no right of appeal against it. Meleri Thomas, from National Autistic Society Cymru , said: Around 1 in 100 children are on the autism spectrum. Every autistic child is dferent but many become overwhelmed in school – by the bright lights, loud noises or other children's unpredictable behaviour. This can result in autistic pupils behaving in ways that seem naughty or disruptive to others when actually they are overwhelmed or distressed. And they can end up being unfairly excluded.

title: mum three who lost childhood
story: NewsMum-of-three who lost childhood memories in horror crash killed herself years later after worrying text messageStacey Coulthard's body was discovered by her son after he awoke to a concerned phone call from one of her pals, an inquest heardShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKathie McInnesSophie Evans07:56, 28 SEP 2018Updated07:59, 28 SEP 2018NewsStacey Coulthard's body was discovered at her Staffordshire home in December last year "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who lost all her childhood memories in a horror crash killed herself years later after battling a series of issues, an inquest has heard. Stacey Coulthard, 38, had visited a pal and had several drinks before walking home with son Kain Elden in the early hours of the morning. After a bite to eat, Kain went up to bed - but he was awoken by a concerned phone call from one of Stacey's friends, the hearing was told. He then discovered his mum's body and alerted emergency services. A post-mortem examination confirmed caring Stacey had died from aspyhxia due to strangulation, with the alcohol she had consumed that night being a contributory factor, StokeonTrent Live reports.  The inquest heard the last contact her own mum, Carol Thompson, had with her was a worrying text message hours before her body was found. The assistant coroner concluded her death was a result of suicide. Stacey, a care home support worker had ‘just got on with it’ whenever she encountered fresh challenges in her le, the hearing was told. But the final turning point came after she was injured at work, which left her with shoulder and neck pains and in need of surgery. She had to take time off to recover from the operation and this led to problems in accessing housing benefit and paying her council rent. By the time she died, she owed thousands of pounds from ious debts. The mum-of-three's body was found at her home in Mollison Road in Meir, Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire, on December 9 last year. The hearing was told she had been visiting a friend the previous evening and had seemed in good spirits. She also had several drinks before walking home with Kain at around 2am, it was said.  Kain said they then had a bite to eat and his mum decided to sleep downstairs. He set up the settee for her and went up to bed himself. However, after being awoken by a phone call from one of her pals, he went downstairs, found her body and alerted the emergency services. The former Newstead Primary and Blurton High pupil had been known as a popular and friendly person, whose talents in sport had shone through during her school days. But when she was around 20 years old, Stacey had been a passenger in a car involved in a motorway pile-up. She suffered a brain injury that led to long-term problems with depression and anxiety, the inquest heard. Mrs Thompson said: “She lost all her childhood memories. She never got them back.” But she described how her daughter had always ‘battled through, no matter what’ and had been determined to keep on working. She had never previously expressed suicidal thoughts, although she was on medication and had received counselling.

title: parents happy puppet syndrome girl
story: NewsParents of 'happy puppet syndrome' girl, 6, reveal pain of knowing she will never marry or have familyLittle Martha Taggart, from Kent, lives in a silent world where she cannot communicate and it breaks her father's heart he won't walk her down the aisleShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom BallAmber Hicks09:17, 28 SEP 2018NewsMartha lives in a silent world "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe parents of a six-year-old girl have told of their pain knowing she will never marry or have a family of her own due to her happy puppet syndrome. Little Martha Taggart lives in a silent world and cannot communicate, has the mental age of a toddler and walks with slightly jerky movements, like a marionette. The smiling, sweet-natured youngster was born with a rare incurable neuro-genetic disorder - officially called Angelman syndrome. Her parents became concerned something was not quite right when she made no noises as a baby, so took her for tests and she was diagnosed with the condition.  Father Lee, 40, who lives with his we Charmaine, 39, Martha and her siblings, Solomon, three, and Norah, two, in Maidstone, Kent, said: I have come to terms with the condition and how it affects Martha. But, sometimes, I will have a little moment to myself when I think about what it will mean for her future. All the things that you take for granted in a person's le - like passing a driving test, going to university and falling in love - she will never get to do. And speaking selfishly, what makes me really upset is the idea that I will never get to walk her up the aisle.  People with what was originally dubbed happy puppet syndrome before being officially named Angelman syndrome in 1965, frequently laugh and smile, are restless and excitable, have a short attention span and a tendency to stick their tongues out. Fortunately, the jerking movements, characteristic of the condition are not pronounced in Martha's case, but she expresses herself solely through gestures and noises. Statistical programmer Charmaine explained: If she wants something she will take your hand and lead you there - take you to the fridge  she's hungry, or to the toilet  she needs the loo. Sometimes, though, she needs words and can't explain herself and I know that makes her very frustrated. But for the most part, she's a very joyful little girl. The name 'happy puppet' is outdated but really does ring true because she is always laughing and smiling - just not speaking.  The couple first suspected something might be wrong with Martha as a baby, as she rarely made any noise. She didn't babble or murmur in the way that babies do, recalled Charmaine, who met her husband at a nightclub in Southampton in 2005, marrying four years later. We took her for tests, but they were inconclusive. It wasn't until she was two and we had DNA testing that we discovered she had this rare genetic disorder called Angelman. It was a devastating blow for Charmaine and Lee, who had never heard of the condition, but were told it normally occurs by chance around the time of conception and those afflicted have a near normal le expectancy. In Martha's case, the impact of the syndrome has become more noticeable with age. Attending a special school for children with learning disabilities, she can become anxious in social situations, although she gets on well with her two younger siblings, neither of whom have Angelman.  Charmaine continued: All our children play very nicely together and get on very well. But the younger two are now beginning to talk and I think they are quite confused about why their older sister can't talk back to them. Although she has a cheery disposition for the most part, Martha's inability to communicate can make her frustrated, causing her to chew her clothes and pull her hair. You can see that it gets Martha worked up, and it's moments like that, when she can't speak to her siblings, that I feel most sorry for her. It's like she's trapped inside this condition, said Charmaine.  She can also experience dficulties in public, when she is surrounded by large groups of people. One Christmas Day, when the family ate out at a restaurant, Martha became overwhelmed by the loud noises and was sick all over her plate. Lee, a health and safety consultant, took her off and walked her along a river next to the restaurant to calm her down as she's feels much more secure outdoors where she has space to wander freely. Martha's behaviour is sometimes unpredictable when she meets new people. Charmaine recalled: When someone she doesn't know comes to the house, she'll get apprehensive and cling to me or Lee. But then after a while she'll get more used to it and she might get up and give the new person a toy. Keen to maintain Martha's quality of le, the couple frequently take their children for days out to National Trust properties, with extensive grounds, where they can enjoy the great outdoors, which Martha is passionate about.

title: psychologist reveals how stop smartphones
story: NewsPsychologist reveals how to stop smartphones and technology from rotting your children's brainsGadgets can have a big impact on young minds - here's everything you need to know to keep them safe from technology overloadsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura Connor22:38, 27 SEP 2018NewsA two-hour smartphone limit is recommended for children "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A two-hour limit on smartphone time can boost children’s brain power, a new study has found.  Scientists discovered a clear link between restricting screen use and improved thinking skills. Canadian researchers looked at 4,520 children aged eight to 11 for the study, which showed that longer breaks from devices help cognitive , while outside activity benefits physical health. So what does too much time with technology actually do to children’s brains, how can you help them cut down, and what should they be doing instead? What can too much screen time do to our children’s brains? Psychologist Dr Susan Marchant-Haycox says brain imaging has shown that frequent users of smartphones tend to have smaller grey matter in the anterior cingulate cortex – the brain region that serves cognition and motor control – which can inhibit a person’s ability to pay attention. She adds that obsessive screen time can cause a greater risk of depression, anxiety, insomnia and impulsive behaviour. One study suggests that smartphone obsession can cause greater levels of the neurotransmitter gamma-Aminobutyric acid, GABA. Susan says: “GABA in the brain’s cortex inhibits neurons, compared to levels of the neurotransmitter called glutamate-glutamine, which energises brain signals. “That will create a chemical imbalance in the brain, which can cause anxiety.  What can too much screen time do to our children socially and physically? Spending too much time glued to a screen can make children introverted due to a lack of social interaction, says Dr Marchant-Haycox. This means that youngsters can “become prisoners to their own mobiles or tablets”. Dr Michael Hogan, a lecturer in psychology at the National University of Ireland, says that smartphone use is a modern extension of children watching television after school – except now they’re watching on portable devices. He said of the gadgets: “They’ve got better and better, which means they are certainly more engaging than they used to be – and will continue to no doubt get more sophisticated. There are lots of techniques which are used to draw people back in again and again. “Our social motivations are pretty much universal and have not changed in the last 20 years, but instead the social engagement is being moved to the screens. “It’s quite easy to engage on a device, so this screen time is taking away from face-to-face time. There is the risk of a child becoming more insular.” A study published this year showed that youths who use social media a lot are at greater risk of sleep disturbance that leads to obesity, while there was a 40% decrease in obesity in those whose parents limited their screen time.  Smartphones and creativity Dr Marchant-Haycox argues that excessive use of mobiles and tablets can also inhibit creative thinking – but there can be some advantages to a child’s development, depending on how the devices are used. “Some research suggests that mobile devices could encourage and support imaginative play, rather than just keeping children occupied,” she says. “But a time limit of mobile or tablet usage must be monitored by parents.” Dr Hogan suggests analysing what your child is like in the presence of other youngsters, to see whether they actively engage in physical, real-le scenarios, or stay buried in their gadgets. He says: “If they turn to their phones when they are in a stimulated environment it may mean you need to monitor their time use.” And he says that while some video games may seem more stimulating than other things, it’s about mixing up dferent activities, in the way you might y your child’s diet.

story: NewsRyanair cancels 250 flights as cabin crew strikes ruin travel plans for 40,000Ryanair's chief operations officer Peter Bellew said the action was "deeply regrettable"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmber Hicks07:30, 28 SEP 2018Updated09:32, 28 SEP 2018NewsA Ryanair boss said it was deeply regrettable "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAround 40,000 travellers are set to have their holiday plans ruined as cabin crew across Europe go on strike - causing Ryanair to have cancelled 250 of its flights.  A dispute over pay and conditions between a host of airlines and staff in six European countries will see them walk out for 24 hours. Ryanair initially cancelled 150 flights due to an unnecessary strike in Spain, Belgium, the Netherlands, Portugal and Italy. But on Thursday the airline said pilots in Germany would also be going on strike, with up to 100 flights shelved as a result. The airline has said that all affected customers have received emails and texts advising them of the cancellations.  Ryanair's chief operations officer Peter Bellew said the action was deeply regrettable. It is deeply disappointing that some of our customers and our people in Germany tomorrow will have their flights disrupted by an unnecessary strike called at short notice, he said. The strikes are the latest in a series of walkouts by staff at Europe's largest low-cost airline. The cancellations account for around 10 percent of its 2,400 scheduled flights on Friday, the airline said this week. On September 12 dozens of flights were cancelled in Germany after pilots and flight attendants refused to work for 24 hours.  In August, several days of strikes involving staff in Ireland, Germany, Sweden, Belgium and the Netherlands saw hundreds of flights cancelled. It was estimated to have affected around 55,000 customers. Meanwhile, earlier this month Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary said strikes by pilots were necessary to keep air fares down. He insisted industrial disputes with the airline's staff have caused minimal disruption as he pledged not to roll over. The Irish airline also says it has made signicant progress in recent weeks in negotiations, including reaching collective labour agreements with staff in Ireland, Britain, Italy and Germany.

Benidorm won’t be the same without it. I’m really gutted, honestly I am.”
